search_result.title: Hurricane Milton updates: Storm has 180-mph winds, targets Florida
search_result.text:
Editor's note: This page reflects the news on Hurricane Milton for Monday, Oct. 7. For the latest updates on Hurricane Milton's path and forecast this week, read USA TODAY's hurricane live coverage for Tuesday, Oct. 8.

Hurricane Milton strengthened to a Category 5 powerhouse Monday, driving sustained winds of 165 mph as it rolled across the Gulf of Mexico bound for what could be a devastating crash Wednesday along Florida's already storm-battered western coast.

The National Hurricane Center said in its 11 p.m. ET advisory that Milton "poses an extremely serious threat to Florida," after earlier warning the hurricane wind speeds had "explosively" intensified. Those speeds increased by 95 mph in 24 hours and by 120 mph in 36 hours.

The storm rapidly strengthened from Category 2 to 5 in just a few hours on Monday. By Tuesday, Milton's intensity "should be dictated by any eyewall replacement cycles, which will likely cause the system to gradually weaken but grow larger," the NHC said.

The center has issued hurricane watches across portions of Florida and warned that parts of the state could be overwhelmed by life-threatening storm surge, flooding rain, and damaging winds.

"Milton is expected to grow in size and remain an extremely dangerous hurricane when it approaches the west coast of Florida on Wednesday," the center said in its 11 p.m. advisory. "A large area of destructive storm surge will occur along parts of the west coast of Florida on Wednesday. This is an extremely life-threatening situation and residents in those areas should follow advice given by local officials and evacuate immediately if told to do so."

Some weakening is forecast before the hurricane reaches the coast but Milton is still likely to be a "large and powerful hurricane" when it makes landfall, according to hurricane center specialist Jack Beven. The center warned that residents in warning areas should complete preparations, such as protecting life and property, by Tuesday night.

Rainfall is expected to total 5-10 inches in some areas of the state that were saturated even before Hurricane Helene smashed ashore less than two weeks ago. Isolated communities could see 15 inches, the hurricane center said. Some areas will be slammed with heavy rainfall well ahead of Milton's arrival, likely later on Tuesday through Wednesday night, the NHC said. A potentially deadly storm surge of 10-15 feet is possible for Tampa and other coastal communities.

Hurricane Milton tracker:Follow projected path of Category 3 storm expected to hit Florida

Developments:

∎ By late Monday, Milton was moving near the northern coast of the Yucatan Peninsula, which was expected to see damaging hurricane-force winds and a life-threatening storm surge with destructive waves through the night.

∎ Milton was centered 630 miles southwest of Tampa as of 11 p.m. ET, moving east at 9 mph. The storm's path places the center of the cone of uncertainty in the Tampa Bay area.

∎ The White House said President Joe Biden has been briefed on preparations for Milton's arrival and on the ongoing response and recovery efforts following Hurricane Helene.

∎ The hurricane center has raised potential storm surge heights in some locations and extended warnings northward along the Atlantic Coast. Storm surge is expected along the eastern Florida Panhandle and south through the Florida Keys, with as much as 15 feet in Tampa Bay.

∎ Tampa International Airport will suspend flight operations at 9 a.m. Tuesday and "reopen when safe to do so." The airport is not a shelter for people or vehicles, authorities said. The Orlando International Airport said it would suspend commercial and private flights Wednesday morning.

∎ California Gov. Gavin Newsom announced 144 state firefighters and other emergency workers will deploy to Florida to help with search and rescue efforts expected to be necessary when Milton hits. The California first responders are just the latest to be sent across the country to help with emergency efforts. Newsom sent 151 firefighters and rescue personnel in the wake of Helene.

Milton one of the 'most intense Atlantic hurricanes' on record

Milton became one of the top five "most intense Atlantic hurricanes" on record Monday night, according to the National Weather Service in Jacksonville, Florida.

As of 8 p.m. ET, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Hurricane Hunters measured a minimum central pressure of 897 mb for Milton — making the hurricane the fifth most intense hurricane in the Atlantic basin by barometric pressure.

Wilma (2005): 882 mb Gilbert (1988): 888 mb Labor Day Hurricane (1935): 892 mb Rita (2005): 895 mb Milton (2024): 897 mb

According to the Southeast Coastal Ocean Observing Regional Association, barometric pressure is the "pressure exerted by the atmosphere at a given point." The lower the barometric pressure, the more intense the winds and the storm are.

Start your day informed: Sign up for USA TODAY's Daily Briefing newsletter for the news you need to know.

Lower wind speeds no consolation, hurricane expert says

One seemingly encouraging aspect of Milton’s frightening development is forecasters’ belief the hurricane’s intensity will diminish before reaching Florida’s west coast, from its current Category 5 to perhaps a Category 3.

Jamie Rhome, deputy director of the National Hurricane Center, said that’s actually not good news.

Speaking to CNN, Rhome said Milton’s winds may decrease from the current 180 mph – they could conceivably dip below the 130 mph threshold for a Category 4 storm – but at the same time the hurricane will get bigger and become more damaging.

“We saw this in Helene,’’ Rhome said. “These big storms, these large-size storms, produce more impact. So this growth in size is going to more than compensate for the reduction in intensity, and it’s going to cause problems because you’re going to get a broader swath of impact, and then things like storm surge are actually made much worse by the bigger size.’’

Rhome pointed out the west side of the Florida peninsula is particularly susceptible to storm surge, as was evidenced late last month by the impact of Helene even though it only delivered a glancing blow to the area. The one-two combination of both major hurricanes so close to each other could be “crippling,’’ he said.

“This case it’s going to be a direct impact, a direct shot, and more powerful at that,’’ Rhome said. “So we’re going to have potentially catastrophic wind damage over a densely populated portion of the Florida peninsula. … Plus, the storm surge is going to be worse than we saw in Helene in some cases.’’

When will Milton hit what city?

The Tampa region will be hit by Milton first, according to AccuWeather. Meteorologists say the hurricane will batter the coastal city from 8 a.m. Wednesday through 2 a.m. Thursday. Up to a foot of rain is expected with 140 mph winds and up to 15 feet of storm surge.

Milton will hit Orlando around 12 p.m. Wednesday through 6 a.m. Thursday, AccuWeather said. Meteorologists forecast the hurricane's winds will slow to 120 mph - a Category 3 hurricane - but expect up to a foot of rain.

The storm is expect to slow as it heads north but reach Jacksonville with near hurricane-force winds, according to forecasters.

Vulnerable Tampa Bay area facing large storm surge

The Tampa Bay metro area has been deemed the nation's most vulnerable to storm surge, and now it's facing a potentially deadly calamity that could inflict more than $200 billion in damage.

Hurricane Milton, now at Category 5, is on track to smash into the region Wednesday and bring a storm surge of up to 15 feet. Some key factors could change before then, including the hurricane's path and level of intensity as it encounters wind shear. But the possibility of large parts of the area being flooded with seawater, perhaps the worst such inundation in more than a century, is very real.

"A severe storm with the right track orientation will cause an enormous buildup of water that will become trapped in the bay and inundate large areas of Tampa and St. Petersburg,'' said a 2015 report from the risk-modeling firm Karen Clark & Company. "Fifty percent of the population lives on ground elevations less than ten feet.''

− Doyle Rice, Janet Loehrke and Dinah Voyles Pulver

Resident of eastern Florida coast 'apprehensive'

Samuel Eames spent the weekend buying batteries and canned food as Hurricane Milton formed in the Gulf of Mexico.

Eames, 70, lives just a few miles from Flagler Beach on the eastern coast of Florida. The longtime resident said it's rare for his community to experience hurricane-force winds from the west, but considering Milton’s power, he’s concerned about the potential damage.

“The weather guys here have been on the air for 20-25 years, and they said they have not dealt with a storm this powerful,” Eames said. “They're not kidding around.”

On Monday, the Navy veteran and retired construction manager said he intends to pick up prescriptions and buy a pair of knee-high boots before hunkering down in his home.

In the wake of Hurricane Helene, swaths of the state have faced rounds of thunderstorms. In Eames’ neighborhood, standing water could be seen “pretty much everywhere,” he said. Forecasters project 6 to 12 inches of rain falling over Flagler and several surrounding counties through Thursday.

“I'm not going to say that I'm worried, but I'm a little apprehensive,” Eames said.

Should there be a Category 6 for new turbocharged hurricanes?

Is there such a thing as a Category 6 hurricane? Not at the moment, but the topic has been discussed.

The long-used Saffir-Simpson hurricane wind scale starts at 74 mph for a Category 1 storm and goes up to Category 5 for any hurricane with sustained wind speeds of 157 mph and above.

The stunningly fast rise of Milton’s wind speeds – increasing by 130 mph to the current 180 mph in 36 hours – has once again raised the question of whether there should be a new category for turbocharged hurricanes. The only five storms known to have produced wind speeds of at least 192 mph – a possible threshold for a new category – have occurred in the last decade, as ocean temperatures have warmed in parts of the world.

However, some weather experts would like to see wind speed categories deemphasized, saying they don’t adequately convey a hurricane’s broader potential impacts such as storm surge and inland flooding. That’s what caused most of the damage from Hurricane Helene in Georgia and the Carolinas.

− Michael Loria and Dinah Voyles Pulver

Significant impact to beaches expected as Milton follows Helene

Florida's coastal area on the west, known for expansive beaches with fine, white sand, is likely to undergo significant change because of Milton, the U.S. Geological Survey said Monday.

Roughly 95% of the sand beaches on that coast are forecast to be continuously covered by waters from the Gulf of Mexico because of the hurricane, causing both erosion and overwash from the water levels covering the tops of sand dunes, the geological survey said.

“The significance of the coastal-change forecast for Milton’s impact to the Florida west coast cannot be overstated, as I believe communities are more vulnerable to this storm’s impacts due to the erosion that occurred recently from Helene,” said Kara Doran, a USGS supervisory physical scientist who works on the forecast.

The agency’s forecast is a worst-case scenario to help provide insight to emergency management officials.

− Dinah Voyles Pulver

Mom shifts into survivalist mode for Milton

For over a week, Elasa Tiernan has grappled with the flood damage to her home in Crystal Beach, in the Tampa Bay area. From hundreds of miles off shore, Hurricane Helene inundated Tiernan’s house in 2 feet of seawater. In the immediate aftermath, Tiernan’s husband – now bedridden because of mold exposure – cleared out the furniture and took a sledgehammer to the cabinets and concrete walls. Now, as Hurricane Milton approaches, one question haunts the lifelong Floridian: Will their home survive?

“I was going to squeegee more water out today, but with this all coming again, we pretty much just had to throw in the towel,” Tiernan, 48, told USA TODAY by phone as she searched for gasoline.

Most of her neighbors suffered the same fate during Helene, and now the streets are lined with “mountains of furniture.” On Monday, she bolted the doors shut, turned off the main breaker and headed for her aunt's house in Tarpon Springs, where she plans to shelter with her husband and daughter.

“I’m going to make sure we have everything we need. I'm a survivalist, I guess,” Tiernan said. “Being a mom of a 14-year-old, you don't really have a lot of time to think otherwise, right?”

Category 5s are the rarest hurricanes

Hurricane Milton is the second Category 5 storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, joining Beryl. Category 5 is the highest rating a hurricane can attain, according to the National Hurricane Center. Maximum sustained winds in excess of 156 mph or higher on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale are required for a hurricane to reach this intensity.

They are the rarest of hurricanes: Weather.com meteorologist Jonathan Erdman said there have only been 40 such hurricanes in the Atlantic Basin since 1924, according to NOAA's historical database.

Since 1950, only five other years have had at least two Atlantic Category 5 hurricanes, according to Colorado State University hurricane researcher Phil Klotzbach: 1961: Esther, Hattie; 2005: Emily, Katrina, Rita, Wilma; 2007: Dean, Felix; 2017: Irma, Maria; 2019: Dorian, Lorenzo.

Only four hurricanes have ever hit the U.S. at Category 5 strength; the most recent being Hurricane Michael in 2018.

− Doyle Rice

How is Hurricane Milton impacting flights?

Flights in the U.S. are not yet being affected by Hurricane Milton, but airlines and airports in the storm’s path are preparing for its impact. Carriers including American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Southwest Airlines and United Airlines have already begun issuing waivers that allow travelers going to or from some Florida airports to change their tickets beginning Monday for no extra charge, even if they purchased a basic economy fare. Customers can check their airline’s website for specific details on travel advisories.

Area airports are open now but say they are monitoring the storm’s path and are prepared to close if necessary. Tampa International Airport said it will suspend operations beginning 9 a.m. Tuesday and will reopen “as soon as it is safe to do so later this week.”

If a flight gets canceled for any reason, customers are entitled to a refund, according to Department of Transportation rules. Travelers should keep an eye on updates from their airline and consider taking advantage of flexible change policies if they don’t have to travel. Read more here.

− Eve Chen, Zach Wichter and Nathan Diller

Gulf Coast residents weary of another state of emergency

Debbie Pace and her family waited in line outside a solid waste facility for almost five hours Sunday night before they could drop off some of the debris Hurricane Helene scattered across their lawn in Palm Harbor, just north of Clearwater. The road to the dump was muddy and several cars had to be towed, said Pace, 52. Meanwhile, lines outside gas stations and supermarkets stretched for blocks as people rushed to pick up supplies.

The approach of Hurricane Milton has plunged Gulf Coast residents – many of whom already were mourning homes and even loved ones from Helene's rage – into a state of emergency, Pace said.

“Maybe five minutes from our home, it looks like a war zone with furniture stacking the streets everywhere,” she said. “We're still in such a state of recovery.”

Far from Florida, Helene cleanup marches on

While Florida braces for Milton, Western North Carolina is still in heavy cleanup mode from Helene. Nearly 1,000 soldiers from Fort Liberty in North Carolina and Fort Campbell in Kentucky are closely working with FEMA to distribute food, water and other desperately needed items, Pentagon spokesperson Pat Ryder said at a briefing. Soldiers are also helping clear emergency routes.

The National Guard has activated more than 6,100 guardsmen, hundreds of high water vehicles and dozens of helicopters and rescue boats from 18 different states, Ryder said.

− Cybele Mayes-Osterman

After Helene, bracing for Milton: 'We're just exhausted'

David Green was expecting to meet Monday with an electrician for a damage estimate on his home, which Hurricane Helene flooded with 3.5 feet of water. Now, for the second time in less than two weeks, he’s again fortifying his home – this time for Hurricane Milton. Green and his wife live on St. Pete Beach, which along with Tampa Bay and surrounding coastal communities, is expected to receive 10-12 feet of storm surge this week.

“We’re just exhausted,” he told USA TODAY.

Green said mounds of debris are still piled up on curbs and buildings are being dug out from under the sand Helene pushed on shore. The 62-year-old said while he’s resigned himself to more flooding, he is worried Milton’s powerful winds could turn the household items into projectiles and cause structural damage.

Early Monday, he rented a truck from Home Depot and packed it with plywood to cover his windows. He plans to wrap up work on the home by Monday night, pack up his fans and dehumidifiers and wait out the storm at his daughter’s home in Ruskin. In the meantime, he’s going to postpone his appointment with his flood insurance company.

“Everything is already gone and out of the house,” he said. “We just have to shut the power off. Then we wait and see … hopefully we can come back.”

'I apologize, this is just horrific': Meteorologist gets weepy talking about Milton

Milton’s raging intensity brought one meteorologist to the point of tears on live television.

“I apologize, this is just horrific,” said NBC 6 hurricane specialist John Morales, his voice cracking and choking back tears after delivering the latest scientific readings of the storm's acceleration.

Morales, an atmospheric and environmental scientist, has four decades of experience as a meteorologist for the National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration and TV stations, according to his LinkedIn.

“The seas are just so incredibly, incredibly hot,” Morales said, watching Milton spin off the coast of Mexico’s Yucatan Peninsula. “Global warming, climate change leading to this and becoming an increasing threat.”

Morales' voice broke as he forecasted the impact Milton will have.

“You’re going to find it very difficult for it to be nothing less than a major hurricane when it makes landfall in Florida,” he said.

Morales' heartfelt show of sympathy for those in the storm's path earned him praise from several people on Youtube, with one user writing, "When a weatherman . . . for the last 50 years starts tearing over a forecast, you know there's big problems coming."

− Michael Loria

Milton sees 'rapid intensification,' explodes to a Cat 4 in about 1 day

Milton grew very strong very fast Monday in what meteorologists call "rapid intensification," which is a dramatic rise in wind speed and a huge drop in barometric pressure in a short amount of time. The phenomenon, which appears to be more common with hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico in recent years, is typically defined to be a tropical cyclone (whether a tropical storm or hurricane) intensifying by at least 35 mph in a 24-hour period.

Milton more than qualified, exploding from a 60-mph tropical storm Sunday morning to a potent 155-mph Category 4 hurricane − an increase of 95 mph in little more than 24 hours.

Rapid intensification is most likely when a tropical storm or hurricane encounters an "extremely conducive environment," Colorado State University hurricane researcher Phil Klotzbach says. That typically means very warm water, low vertical wind shear and high levels of midlevel moisture.

− Dinah Voyles Pulver and Doyle Rice

Disney World not taking reservations for Tuesday, Wednesday

Walt Disney World theme parks were still open to the public Monday. Disney, however, was not taking park reservations for Tuesday and Wednesday. Disney had posted a hurricane update on its Disney World weather updates and information page: “Walt Disney World Resort is currently operating under normal conditions. We are closely monitoring the path of the projected storm as we continue to prioritize the safety of our guests and cast members. To ensure you have a magical visit to Walt Disney World Resort, we encourage you to prepare for the local climate and check the weather forecast for Central Florida. Check back for important weather updates."

− Jennifer Sangalang

Mandatory evacuation orders expected Monday

Pinellas, Manatee and Sarasota were among counties expected to announce evacuation orders Monday. Pinellas County, which includes the city of St. Petersburg, was planning to announce mandatory evacuations for 500,000 people in the low-lying areas, Sheriff Bob Gualtieri said Sunday. He urged people to heed evacuation orders after he said too many ignored them for Helene, resulting in 12 deaths in the county and 1,500 emergency calls that went unanswered.

The county already ordered the evacuation of six hospitals, 25 nursing homes and 44 assisted living facilities totaling 6,600 patients, said Cathie Perkins, director of the county's emergency management. School was canceled through Wednesday.

Kevin Guthrie, director of Florida's emergency management division, said the state was preparing for the largest evacuation since Hurricane Irma in 2017, when more than 6 million Floridians were forced to flee their homes.

From rescue to recovery:The grim task in flood-ravaged western North Carolina

What does declaring a state of emergency in Florida mean?

Gov. Ron DeSantis has declared a state of emergency for 51 of Florida's 67 counties ahead of Milton. Declaring a state of emergency allows the state and local governments more freedom to coordinate emergency agencies and relax restrictions.

The governor may suspend regulations that would slow emergency response, commandeer private property needed to deal with the emergency, order evacuations, and direct or delegate control of the National Guard to help rescue or cleanup operations. DeSantis also could suspend the sale of alcohol, guns, explosives and combustibles, establish emergency housing, limit power services as needed, and impose or allow exceptions to curfews. Read more here.

− C. A. Bridges, USA TODAY NETWORK - Florida

Contributing: Reuters

search_result.title: What does 'homecoming' really mean?
search_result.text:
Courtney Crowder

ccrowder@dmreg.com

Recently, over coffee and chitchat, a friend, Kyrstin, and I contemplated gravel roads.

The “You’re Not an Iowan” feature my colleague Kyle Munson wrote about a true Iowan’s need to embrace the eccentricities of gravel roads touched Kyrstin as a perfect summation of “home,” she told me.

“Raise a hand if the dusty rural school-bus ride was a staple of your childhood?” Munson wrote.

Reading that line, Kyrstin’s hand was raised with the enthusiasm of a third-grader eager to hear her own voice.

For me, not so much. A Chicago transplant who attended college in New York City, my childhood was defined by alleys, traffic and storefronts. Those, along with takeout and Metrocards, add up to my summation of “home.”

From homesteads to high-rises, both the word and the concept of "home" have fluid meanings. My definition is probably not your definition. In fact, if I asked 100 people the real meaning of “home,” I think I’d get 100 different answers.

At the Register’s upcoming Homecoming edition of the Des Moines Storytellers Project — a live oral storytelling event that bows at 6:30 p.m. Oct. 14 at the Staplin Performing Arts Center — you’ll hear about seven different experiences with "home."

But more than just four walls and a roof, these tales will reflect on the emotions of home: warmth, safety, freedom and the relief of finding a place to let your freak flag fly high.

The stories will reflect the quilt of Iowans’ experiences and perspectives of home and push the boundaries of what you thought it meant to leave — or finally discover — your very own corner of comfort.

Some storytellers will be hilarious, others will be heartrending. Some will make you laugh, others will make you weep.

No matter your thoughts and feelings surrounding the idea of "home," these storytellers will offer angles, opinions and yarns you never even considered pondering.

Now, we don't want to ruin the surprise regarding what these stories are about (you'll just have to come and listen Oct. 14), but we do want to tell you a little bit about these storytellers’ backgrounds.

Check out the seven community members, neighbors and friendly morning anchors who will be sharing their stories live, onstage on Oct. 14.

Des Moines Storytellers Project: Homecoming

6:30 p.m., Oct. 14, the Staplin Performing Arts Center at Valley High School, 3650 Woodland Ave., West Des Moines

Tickets range from $10-$25 and are available at DesMoinesRegister.com/Storytellers. Prices for all tickets, subject to availability, will increase by $5 at the door.

The storytellers

Eric Hanson

Eric Hanson has been telling stories on KCCI-TV for 16 years, many of which have been about the characters around our home state. Eric’s alarm clock rings at 2:45 a.m. when he leaves to anchor KCCI’s morning news. Later, he works on his “This is Iowa” packages, which have earned six national awards and five Emmys. Eric grew up on a farm between Roland and Story City, graduated from Wartburg College and reported in Eau Claire, Wisc., and Waterloo before returning home to central Iowa. He lives in West Des Moines with his wife, son and daughter.

Olivia Samples

Olivia Samples is in her third and final year studying public relations and women’s and gender studies at Simpson College. She is involved on campus as a sexual assault advocate and advertising director and writer for the college newspaper. She also interns for Yoga For First Responders. Originally from Charlotte, N.C., Olivia is beginning to call Des Moines "home."

Jo Kay Boyle

Two passions — Southern hospitality and spirituality — provide the perfect blend for this tea aficionado to keep her daily cup overflowing. Losing her husband to ALS as well as enduring three additional family deaths in recent years, Jo Kay has experienced blessings through her nightmares of grief. An extroverted, recently retired school psychologist, she is currently collecting stories along her journey, which she hopes to be the subject of an upcoming book.

Steve Danielson

Steve Danielson is a 19-year veteran of Register Media's advertising department. Prior to his career with the Register, Steve was in broadcasting as both an on-air talent and in advertising sales. He is a member of the Greater Carlisle Area Chamber of Commerce Board of Directors and a graduate of the 2016 Warren County Economic Development Leadership Institute. A father of four and grandfather of two, Steve is an avid Iowa State fan.

Esam Boraey

Esam Boraey is a human rights activist working for freedom and democracy in the Middle East. This passion led him to play a key role in the Egyptian revolution of 2011, which helped overthrow Hosni Mubarak. Esam taught classes and studied for his master’s degree in international relations at Cairo University before leaving for the U.S. In 2013, Esam was honored as a "Freedom Fighter" by the secretary of transportation Ray LaHood. His work has received many accolades from organizations in the Middle East.

Jack Schuler

Jack Schuler is an English teacher at Abraham Lincoln High School, where he assists with the GSA and theater activities. Born in Streator, Ill., Jack attended Briar Cliff University, graduating in 2005 with a bachelor’s degree in theater and enlisting in the Marine Corps in 2006. Upon discharge, he went back to Briar Cliff and earned a bachelor’s degree in secondary education. Jack is active in politics, holding positions in the Iowa Democratic Party, assisting with campaigns and becoming possibly the first openly transgender member of the Electoral College.

Kyrstin Shelley

Kyrstin Shelley calls many places "home." Home is Maquoketa in eastern Iowa, where she grew up; Ames, where she first lived on her own; and Hogwarts, where she resides in daydreams. Home is also Des Moines with her husband, Will, and two fur-babies, Waffles and Artie. Kyrstin, a graduate of Grand View University, is currently a teacher-librarian. When she isn’t at school, you can find her laughing with friends and family, training for a half-marathon or binging on her never-ending to-read pile.

Learn more

Do you have a story to tell? Email a brief 10-sentence summary of the story you'd like to tell to storytellers@dmreg.com and one of our coaches will be in touch.

2017 lineup

We will release dates, themes and venues for our 2017 suite of storyteller events soon. (We promise!) Keep your eyes peeled for more information on tickets and tellers in these pages and online at DesMoinesRegister.com/Storytellers.

search_result.title: Arizona 2020 election updates: State turns blue, votes for Kelly ...
search_result.text:
Arizona Republic

It's the day after the election. Voters across the United States are waiting for outstanding ballots to be counted in a close presidential race. In Arizona, Democrats Joe Biden and Mark Kelly helped turn the state blue.

Arizonans decided to legalize recreational marijuana, joining New Jersey, Montana and South Dakota where similar proposals were ahead in the polls.

Other state and local races are still undecided.

Here's the latest:

Democrat Joe Biden takes Arizona, turning the state blue for the first time in 24 years.

Democrat Mark Kelly defeats Republican Sen. Martha McSally in a U.S. Senate race with national implications.

Maricopa County Attorney Allister Adel has been admitted to the hospital.

Sign-up for Your Vote: Text with the USA TODAY elections team.

Follow along for updates throughout Election Day from Arizona Republic reporters.

SEE THE WINNERS: Arizona election results

4:30 a.m.: Dems maintain control of House; GOP holding on to Senate

In the race to control Congress, Democrats appear to have held on to the House, though their chances of flipping the Senate look slim.

Democrats gained a Senate seat in Arizona and Colorado, but Republicans fended off challenges in several battleground states that President Donald Trump has carried.

Democrats needed at least three wins to flip the Senate, four if Trump wins reelection. Republicans currently hold 53 seats, while Democrats have 45. There are two independents who caucus with Democrats.

— USA TODAY

3:40 a.m.: Presidential race close as Americans wake up on East Coast

Neither presidential candidate has received the necessary 270 electoral college votes to win the election as Americans on the East Coast begin to wake up.

Battleground states Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin — which likely will determine the election — are still up for grabs.

Democrat Joe Biden helped flip Arizona, but he didn't secure needed wins in other swing states like Texas, Florida and Ohio. Republican President Donald Trump, who carried those three states, secured wins in Montana, Nebraska, North and South Dakota and throughout much of the southern United States.

Biden has 238 electoral votes and Trump 213 as of 3:40 a.m. Arizona time.

— USA TODAY

3:15 a.m.: Groups plan rallies on Wednesday

A group that says it is working to ensure that the Trump campaign doesn't interfere with vote counts has dozens of events planned nationwide on Wednesday, including three in Arizona.

Protect the Results, a joint effort by progressive grassroots groups Indivisible and Stand Up America, announced on its website that it planned to mobilize people across the country to ensure that all votes are counted.

In Arizona, the group plans to host a rally at 11:30 a.m. in Tucson, 1 p.m. in Flagstaff and 3 p.m. in Yuma, though it appeared that times and locations weren't yet finalized.

"With every tweet and refusal to commit to accepting the legitimate results of the 2020 election, Trump seeks to stoke chaos and fear," the organization said. "But we will be ready."

In Flagstaff, leftist organization Flagstaff Direct Action is hosting a 5 p.m. rally at Heritage Square, the organization announced on Instagram. The group encouraged attendees to wear a mask and social distance and said that "no matter who wins, our struggles continue."

While election night in Arizona was fairly quiet, protesters clashed in cities across the country as votes were tallied.

Dozens marched in Los Angeles and crowds of 200 or more were in Raleigh, North Carolina, and Portland, Oregon. Minnesota saw more than a dozen arrests.

— Paulina Pineda and USA TODAY

2:15 a.m.: Biden campaign to fight Trump campaign's efforts to stop vote count

Democrat Joe Biden's campaign says it will fight any efforts by President Donald Trump's campaign to go to the U.S. Supreme Court to prevent ballots from being tabulated.

In a statement sent before 4 a.m. Eastern time on Wednesday, Biden campaign manager Jen O'Malley Dillon called Trump's statement that he will “be going to the U.S. Supreme Court” and that he wants “all voting to stop” “outrageous, unprecedented and incorrect.”

O'Malley Dillon says the Biden campaign has “legal teams standing by ready to deploy to resist that effort.” And she says, “They will prevail.”

The Associated Press has not declared a winner in the presidential race. There are still hundreds of thousands of votes left to be counted, and the outcome hinges on a handful of uncalled battleground states.

— The Associated Press

1 a.m.: Arizona turns blue, votes for Democrat Joe Biden as president; national race is too close to call

The Associated Press has called the state of Arizona for Democrat Joe Biden. The national presidential race between Biden and incumbent President Donald Trump is too close to call.

Biden's win in Arizona is the first presidential victory for a Democratic candidate since 1996 when Bill Clinton won the state.

The 2016 presidential election saw Arizona on the verge of being competitive for Democrats with Trump's margins much thinner than the Republicans before him. He carried the state by about 3.5 points.

Arizona was the first state to flip in the presidential race though several key swing states remained up in the air Wednesday morning.

Nationwide, Trump and Biden each claimed early and predictable state calls, with Trump projected to win Kentucky, Tennessee, Mississippi, Alabama and North and South Carolina. Biden locked down a slew of blue states in the Northeast, including his home state of Delaware, Massachusetts, New Jersey and New York.

But votes were still being tallied in battleground states like Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin, that will ultimately determine the election.

— Rachel Leingang

1 a.m.: Mark Kelly defeats Martha McSally in Senate race

Democrat Mark Kelly defeated Republican Martha McSally in Arizona's U.S. Senate race with national implications, according to The Associated Press.

Kelly, a first-time candidate, is a retired NASA astronaut, gun-control advocate and husband of former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords, D-Ariz.

He will fill the remainder of late Sen. John McCain's term and is expected to be sworn in as soon as election results are certified.

A McSally campaign spokesperson signaled after the race was called that McSally, who was appointed to the seat in 2018, was not giving up on the race.

"Hundreds of thousands of votes have still not been counted," Caroline Anderegg said in a written statement. "Every Arizonan deserves to have their voice heard and voted counted. We continue to monitor returns."

— Yvonne Wingett Sanchez

12:50 a.m.: Trump declares early victory, despite many votes outstanding

President Donald Trump said he was sweeping most battleground states and was well on his way to victory during remarks early Wednesday at the White House.

However, he sought to sow distrust in the vote-counting process in several key swing states, repeating many false claims about how elections work.

He said his team was gearing up for a big celebration after winning states like Georgia, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Texas when “it was all called off.” He said he hasn’t been declared a winner in many of those states though he is leading by a wide margin that Biden can’t overcome.

Early results show Trump is leading Biden in crucial swing states, but there are many votes left to count.

Trump said he planned to go to the U.S. Supreme Court to prevent states from counting outstanding ballots late into the night, which he called a “fraud.”

However, in Arizona, where he is trailing Biden by several points, Trump said it was too soon to call the race. He said there were many votes left to count and that he shouldn't be discounted yet, contradicting his comments about other swing states with large number of outstanding votes where he has falsely claimed he had won.

He said it would’ ve been “nice” to win but that winning Arizona wasn’t necessary to getting elected to a second term.

— Rachel Leingang and Paulina Pineda

12:30 a.m.: Dem grassroots groups celebrate possibility of turning Arizona blue

Votes were still being counted in Arizona when cheers erupted from community organizers in south Phoenix who declared they were turning the state blue.

Down-ballot victories for Democratic candidates in the traditional Republican stronghold were celebrated as “vindication of all the pain and suffering we’ve seen in the community.”

Activists from the Unite Here labor union, CASE Action social justice group and Living United for Change grassroots organization applauded voter drives that they said helped bring thousands of young voters to the polls in 2020.

Organizers outside the CASE Action offices on Seventh Avenue just before 11 p.m. said just “showing up” was a victory.

“Never in my life did I think we would be up in the air here in Arizona,” said Marisela Mares, 22, referring to a presidential election that was too close to call. “It could be a very close race. We’re pushing that margin.”

Mares, who started organizing with Unite Here eight years ago at 14, said Arizona has evolved from a red state in 2010 to a purple state in 2018 to a blue one on Tuesday night. Organizers for years have made a determined effort to convince Hispanic and young voters that they could make a difference, Mares said.

“I think it’s a lot more blue than we were, even just two years ago,” Mares said. “I don’t know what color is between blue and purple, but we are there.”

Unite Here organizer Maria Hernandez said union members, primarily hospitality workers, many of whom have lost their jobs during the COVID-19 pandemic, blitzed the state since June, knocking on as many as 800,000 doors.

“The fact that we got to this point in Arizona is no accident,” she said. “We are instilling hope where there was once fear.”

Tuesday’s results proved when the community comes together, it can speak with a powerful voice, said Stephanie Maldonado, campaign director for Living United for Change in Arizona, or LUCHA.

“We were told, ‘Latinos don’t show up.’ But Latinos showed up,” she said. “We showed up, we voted early and we trusted a system. It was 10 years in the making; 10 years to get to today, 10 years to ensure our voices, our families and our communities were represented.”

Maldonado said the movement was led by people under 30. She said they were motivated by anger over SB 1070, Arizona’s notorious immigration measure passed in 2010, which targeted undocumented immigrants with some of the strictest laws in the country.

“Young people showed up and represented in Arizona,” she said. “Why? Because 10 years ago, we couldn’t vote. Ten years ago, we saw our parents and our community impacted by SB 1070, and tonight young people showed up and we won.”

— Robert Anglen

11:45 p.m.: 2 people say they couldn't vote after being kicked out of vote center

Two siblings say they were among a small group of voters denied a vote and removed by law enforcement from a vote center in downtown Phoenix on Tuesday evening despite being in line by the 7 p.m. cutoff.

It was one of only a few allegations of voters being turned away from polling sites in Arizona as of Tuesday night, and the only one involving law enforcement.

Timitria Thompson, 22, and her 24-year-old brother, Adrion Thompson, told The Republic that they were in line at 7 p.m. when they were asked to leave a polling place near Seventh and Southern avenues because it had closed.

The siblings said they insisted on being allowed to vote but that a man running the polling location kept trying to kick them out and eventually called police.

At least four Maricopa County Sheriff's Office deputies responded to the scene and threatened to arrest Timitria Thompson on suspicion of trespassing and disorderly conduct, she said.

After waiting in the polling place for more than an hour, Timitria Thompson said law enforcement eventually pushed her out.

A Sheriff's Office spokesperson confirmed deputies were at the scene but said they "did not take any law enforcement actions." A Phoenix Police Department spokesperson said the Sheriff's Office called Phoenix police to the scene but no arrests were made.

— Chelsea Curtis

11:20 p.m.: County Recorder Fontes says voting went without a hitch

Maricopa County Recorder Adrian Fontes told The Republic after polls closed Tuesday that voting went "very, very well."

A couple dozen locations had long lines after polls closed, but workers got them in and out quickly, he said.

Throughout the day, very few voters had to wait more than 45 minutes.

There were a few snafus, he said, including some printers that ran out of ink. But those problems were addressed quickly.

5 p.m.: Queen Creek voters allege voter harassment

“One of our field volunteers reported this issue and had the voter call into the hotline,” Election Protection spokesperson Ian Weiner said via email Tuesday afternoon.

“We received this complaint and were able to mobilize our coalition to address and ultimately resolve the issue. We sent a team of trained de-escalators (called “Election Defenders”) and raised it to the Secretary of State who also alerted the county to get the matter resolved," he said.

A spokeswoman for the Maricopa County Recorder’s office said she heard that individuals had yelled at voters, but that if it occurred outside the 75-foot limit surrounding polling places it was not illegal.

She added that anyone outside the 75-foot limit was also allowed to photograph anyone going into or out of a polling place.

She said the office also received reports that people were telling voters outside the polling place that they should use ballpoint pens on their ballots instead of the Sharpie pens provided in the voting booths.

Voters can use ballpoint pen in black or blue ink or a Sharpie, and vote centers use fine-tip Sharpies as they have the fastest drying ink. If ballpoint ink is not allowed to dry completely, it can smudge off onto the optical readers and spoil other ballots, according to the Maricopa County Recorder's Office.

A plainclothes Maricopa County Sheriff's deputy was sent to investigate and found that a woman was handing voters ballpoint pens with a flyer urging them to not use sharpies. 3 p.m.: 'A lemonade stand for democracy' in south Phoenix

Volunteers from United Farm Workers — some coming from other states in the West to focus on swing-state Arizona — have been hitting the pavement for months reaching voters in south Phoenix.

On Tuesday, the culmination of their efforts is a voter information booth at El Reposo Park, the site of the "Low Ridin' for Biden" event on Sunday, one of the organization’s last hurrahs to mobilize voters.

Organizers prepared a single table with treats and water in a cozy south Phoenix neighborhood between Seventh Street and Central Avenue.

“I would say, if anything, it’s a lemonade stand for democracy,” Elizabeth Strater, a UFW volunteer from California, said of the humble table. “Because this is a community that doesn’t feel represented, these are folks that may not know where they’re supposed to vote.”

So far, a little more than 35 people showed up to ask for information.

Communities like south Phoenix, which is home to some of the poorest neighborhoods in Phoenix and has the highest Black and Latino populations in the city, are often disproportionately affected by voter disenfranchisement. Often, the community is skeptical of candidates and information just doesn’t reach voters.

“The majority of people do want to be engaged, they just don’t have the tools to be engaged,” said Ernie Flores, a UFW volunteer from Yuma. “There’s no perfect representation, as Cesar Chavez said. There’s no perfect democracy, but there is perfect participation.”

He said it seems possible that Arizona will turn blue because of its Latino population, if not now, then in the future. He said Trump’s message to Latinos was that he was against them right off the bat, and that encouraged Latino voters to vote against him.

— Megan Taros

2:30 p.m.: Maricopa County approaches 100,000 voters

Maricopa County Recorder Adrian Fontes said voter turnout in the county is in line with what officials expected, with about 99,000 voters casting ballots in person before 1:30 p.m.

That doesn't include other voters who dropped off their mail-in ballots at the polls.

Jordy and Alexis Berrelleza did just that.

The Phoenix siblings said they wanted to cast their first votes together. After their ballots arrived in the mail, Jordy, 19, walked his sister through the choices, explaining the options as simply as he could.

“In a non-biased way,” he said, grinning under his black mask, but the siblings voted mostly the same way anyway.

Before Election Day, they thought about mailing in their ballots, but all the noise surrounding the integrity of the election changed their minds.

“We felt like it was more secure to bring it in person,” Jordy said. So together they headed to the offices of the Phoenix Union High School District, where there was a steady stream of voters but no line.

In the end, Jordy said, they probably didn’t have any reason to worry.

“It would’ve been the same,” he said of mailing in their votes, “because we just dropped it in a box."

— Alden Woods and Mary Jo Pitzl

2 p.m.: Navajo voters cast ballots

Navajo voters streamed into the Steamboat Chapter House in Steamboat, Arizona, to cast their votes in Apache county.

Several election officials paced the grounds, instructing voters which line to stand in. There was a line to vote in Apache County for the national and state election, and a line for local Navajo Nation government elections.

The voting line for the county moved quickly and the local voting line had build up as more and more people turned out to vote.

Election officials made sure people in line maintained social distancing, kept face masks on and knew about hand-washing stations. They also checked temperatures before voters entered the building.

Andrew Simpson and his wife Bessie Yellowhair-Simpson, from Steamboat in northeastern Arizona, showed up at the polls to observe while they waited for family members to arrive from Phoenix. They both voted early by mail, but as community leaders — Andrew is a former council delegate and Bessi is the chapter treasurer — they stick around every Election Day.

Bessie, who is up for reelection, said she is use to seeing food stands lined up against the fence to feed voters before they head into the polls, but they couldn’t do that this year. The Navajo Nation Board of Elections sent out a memo before Election Day advising against food stands or political tents due to the pandemic.

“We just wanted to see people and our relatives,” he said, and he’s been able to recognize most of them through their masks. “There is still life out here.”

Andrew feels that both major political parties haven’t spent enough time on the Navajo Nation to really understand the way of life for Navajo people. But he has noticed that they’re paying more attention to Indigenous communities.

“Nobody ever paid attention to who we are," he said. He hopes in a few years it will only get better.

“They need to come here to understand us rather than try to change us into their way of life,” Andrew said. “Not only the Navajo Nation but all Native tribes. They need to understand our way of life.”

— Shondiin Silversmith

1:30 p.m.: Advocates say Native American voters see problems at polling sites

Volunteers say they've heard of issues at polling locations in Apache County.

Volunteers with Native Vote said they’ve received reports from Native American voters witnessing problems at polling sites. Patty Ferguson Bohnee leads Native Vote Arizona, an organization that protects against violations of Native American's voting rights and trains volunteers to monitor polling sites for problems.

She said they’ve received reports that polling sites in Apache County, including in Chinle and Window Rock, did not open on time this morning. That means some voters may have had to wait or leave if they had to work.

Ferguson Bohnee urged voters who experience or witness violations of voting rights to contact the Native Vote hotline at 888-777-3831 so attorneys can document and investigate the complaints.

Further south, three members of the Arizona State University's Indigenous pageant royalty supported the Native Vote at Bapchule, a community in the Gila River Indian Community.

Miss Indigenous ASU Lourdes Pereira is a member of the federally recognized Hia-Ced O'odham but is enrolled at Tohono O'odham Nation. Pereira, a double major in American Indian and justice studies, said that one issue important to her is ensuring Native people can access ballots and return them from remote tribal communities while avoiding COVID-19 exposure.

The tribe instituted drive-thru voting, which First Attendant Jolene Fernandez said was a boon for elders, because it kept them from close contact with poll workers.

The tribe was also conducting its own election for council and an initiative to change the tribal constitution in regards to tribal membership.

— Dianna M. Náñez, Debra Utacia Krol

12:45 p.m.: Lines still long in Scottsdale, issues in Tucson

Lines in Old Town Scottsdale started growing shortly after the polling place at the Old Town venue Mini Social opened for voting Tuesday morning.

By the afternoon, the Maricopa County Recorder's Office website showed there were still dozens of people in line and wait times stretched upward of 20 minutes.

Lines at polling places across the Valley have moved smoothly throughout the late morning and early afternoon. Dozens of locations listed on the county recorder's website showed wait times between zero and 10 minutes.

Volunteers say the police were called in Tucson on a man trying to influence voters to reelect President Donald Trump outside the Miller-Golf Links Library.

Roger Dean, a registered Democrat, has been outside of the polling site since 7 a.m. with a sign that reads "Democrats for Trump."

“Two police officers showed up,” Dean said. “They had complaints of me standing here (intimidating) people.”

He added that he is allowed to be at the polling site as long as he is at the 75 feet marker.

Leo Kresch, a 22-year-old who recently moved to Tucson, said she has also been at this polling location all day, and was there when the police were called.

— Raphael Romero Ruiz, Joshua Bowling

Noon: Volunteers offer resources ahead of potential lunch rush

Volunteers stood outside Valley polling places Tuesday morning as they waited for a potential surge of voters during the lunch hour.

Promise Arizona was on-site at Mountain Park Health Center encouraging people to get out the vote. Some arrived in a white pickup adorned with red and blue streamers, American flags and "Vote!" written along the door.

Volunteers and employees held banners in English and Spanish with the messages "Vote today" and "Sí se puede."

"We are making sure voters are supported when they come cast their vote and if we see anything suspicious or anything that’s out of place we will help them and provide guidance," Manuel Gutierrez with Promise Arizona said.

In northwest Phoenix near 35th and Northern avenues, dozens of members of Unite Here Local 11, a labor union that represents 33,000 hotel and food service workers in southern California and Arizona, fanned out into the neighborhoods for one final day of knocking on doors.

"This is the day we are going to turn Arizona blue," Alex Sandoval, a Unite Here organizer and campaign field director, told the group before sending them out into the field.

Voting-rights advocates said that in an election with historic turnout, voters who don’t speak English or experience other barriers to voting may struggle to reach help when they believe their rights are being violated. Chris Gilfillan, a director with the Arizona Center for Empowerment and Living United for Change in Arizona, was working with voter protection groups providing support in Spanish and other languages.

"Anyone can help reporting voting flags (problems) using the incident reporting form," he said.

Patty Ferguson Bohnee leads Native Vote Arizona, an organization that protects against violations of Native American's voting rights. She urged people who experience or witness problems for Native American voters to call the Native Vote hotline or reach out to volunteers at polling sites.

Arizona political parties have provided hotlines to assist voters who only feel comfortable seeking help for potential violations from someone with their party of preference.

Voter-assistance hotlines:

NALEO ¡Ve y Vota! Spanish/English languages: 888-839-8682

Native Vote: 888-777-3831

Arab American Institute Arabic/English languages:844-925-5287

APIA VOTE and AAJC Asian languages: 888-274-8683

Lawyers’ Committee for Civil Rights Under Law/10 languages: 866-687-8683

Arizona Center for Disability Law: 602-274-6287

Arizona Republican Party: 602-926-2877

Arizona Democratic Party: 833-868-3429

— Dianna M. Náñez, Megan Taros, Daniel Gonzalez

11:30 a.m.: Religious polling places in the East Valley

The Islamic Center of the Northeast Valley in Scottsdale was one of two mosques serving as a polling location in Maricopa County this year. Around 40 people formed a line outside the mosque early in the day, but the line started moving quickly.

Voter Cat Splete said it took her about a minute total to drop off her ballot. This is Splete’s first time voting in a presidential election. Climate justice is the key issue that moved her to vote, she said.

“It goes into the environmental humanities — those who live in minority communities are always going to bear the brunt of those negative environmental factors," she said.

Many voters at the center were not Muslim. That's because Muslims were encouraged to vote early this year, according to Ahmed Soussi, the interim director for the Council of American-Islamic Relation’s Arizona chapter.

CAIR is a part of the One Arizona, a coalition that mobilizes and educates voters from marginalized communities. One Arizona said on Twitter they registered about 185,000 voters this year.

The Sun Lakes United Methodist Church in Chandler did not see large crowds Tuesday morning.

Two woman, who dubbed themselves “The Two Phyllises”, have spent the morning handing out fliers that they made for Republicans to help them narrow down their votes.

Phyllis Lester, who already submitted her early ballot, said she came up with the idea for the fliers when she and her husband realized how many judges there were to choose from on their ballot this election.

— Farah Eltohamy, Kelly Donohue

11 a.m.: Complaint of man in Trump mask yelling at voters

There was a complaint Tuesday morning of a man yelling at Scottsdale voters.

John Ainlay, a prescient committee member for Legislative District 23, said a man in a Trump mask yelled at voters as they went to cast their ballots around 9 a.m. at Florence Ely Nelson Desert Park in north Scottsdale.

The man allegedly yelled things like "baby killers" and "stop stealing my taxes." Ainlay said a woman from the Arizona Republican Party threatened to call the police on the man if he continued. He quieted down but remained at the voting site, Ainlay said.

Nonpartisan volunteers at the site said they were not able to remove him because he was outside the allowed 75 foot boundary, but they expressed concern over his presence and attempts to intimidate voters.

— Farah Eltohamy

10:30 a.m.: Smooth voting in Tucson, Cordes Lakes

Estevan Puentes, a 39-year-old south Tucson resident, came out to vote with his family Tuesday morning.

His mother only speaks and reads in Spanish. That can be a problem when polling sites do not have any Spanish speakers or ballots that she can understand, Puentes said.

He brought his son and nephew who are first-time voters, as well as his sister to make sure his family’s votes were counted this election. They were able to get in and out quickly as there was no sizable line at the polling place.

In Cordes Lakes, a turn off Interstate 17 on the drive to northern Arizona, voters weren't blocked by long lines either.

The Cordes Lakes Community Center had a short line, people were mostly masked and many donned pro-Trump paraphernalia. A steady flow of cars ambled in and out of the gravel parking lot. Tranquil and quiet under expansive clouded skies, it was hard to believe people were there to cast their votes in the explosive 2020 presidential election.

Around 9:45 a.m., it began to rain, but people still stood dutifully outside.

Randy Rogers and Angie McFadin emerged from their white truck. Issues about the border and health care brought both to the polls near their home.

“I don’t like our two candidates, I’ll say that. I’m not a fan of either one of them,” Rogers said, walking toward the line stretching from the doorway of the one-story community center. “I was a Trump supporter last time because I liked what he had to say, and I’m definitely not a Democrat. Republicans want to take everything and Democrats want to give everything away.”

Unlike 2016, he said he isn’t voting for Trump in this election. For the first time in his life, he’s casting his vote for the third-party candidate on the ballot, Jo Jorgensen.

The change was largely due to the handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, Roger said. The infection had swept through his sister-in-law’s entire family.

“For me, I can’t vote for these two guys with a clear conscience,” he aid.

— Raphael Romero Ruiz, Emily Wilder

10:15 a.m.: Rain in Gilbert, lines in Scottsdale

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints had to close its doors and people made a dash for the dry interiors of their cars as rain came down in Gilbert.

Recent ASU graduate Cameryn Baum stood outside of the Higley Road polling station with her cello this morning. She hoped to inspire more people to head inside and vote.

Baum said she is participating in the nationwide Play for the Vote campaign, which is organizing musical performances throughout the country during Election Day to provide a positive incentive for people to head to the polls.

In Old Town Scottsdale, lines were long.

Earlier in the morning, more than 100 people waited in line to vote outside Mini Social, a multi-use events venue in Old Town Scottsdale.

The line of voters curved and winded around the store fronts of Fifth Avenue. Some people walking up to vote expressed sighs of frustration.

Scottsdale City Council candidate Betty Janik was making her way steadily through the line at 8 a.m., talking to voters about issues and answering their remaining questions about the candidates.

By 9 a.m. a volunteer had come outside to tell voters that there were several polling locations within four to six miles of Mini Social that had no wait times.

Minutes later, there were roughly 80 people in line with a wait time of 20 minutes.

— Kelly Donohue, Lorraine Longhi

9:45 a.m.: 'Hope that people are going to come together'

Voters were largely optimistic at the Southern Plaza voting center in south Phoenix.

Many emphasized the importance of the vote particularly in this tense and chaotic year, especially as Arizona stands on the precipice of historic change.

“If anything if Arizona stays Trump but then turns blue it’s going to be an interesting time in the country,” said voter Sentari Minor as he left the polling center.

The atmosphere was friendly as political opponents and compatriots appealed to voters outside the center. Mia Hill, another voter at the center, said that despite tension leading in to the election that the outcome must be a call to unity.

"It was important to me that I bought and contribute to a positive future," Hill said. "The fear of negative things happening, I think that’s all it is, is fear. I have hope that people are going to come together more than everything."

Jesus Olvera has children in school in south Phoenix. For him, the school board race was most important for his children’s future — but all the votes he cast were laying a foundation for them, he said.

He and other voters agreed the climate is ripe for change.

"I think there’s going to be a big change. I don’t know if it’s going to bring the results but it’s going to be a good time for us," Olvera said.

— Megan Taros

9:30 a.m.: Rep. Debbie Lesko alleges 'bias' at polling location

Rep. Debbie Lesko tweeted on Tuesday morning that a county poll worker in Sun City moved polling lines without measuring them and told Lesko she had to leave.

Lesko tweeted that she was at Radiant Church Sun City, near 107th Avenue and Boswell Bouelvard, when this happened.

"This is what's typical of some people that are biased," Lesko said in the video. "And it's wrong."

Megan Gilbertson, a spokesperson for the Maricopa County Elections Department, said workers at the site mistakenly thought it was a non-electioneering site. In Arizona, people aren't allowed to campaign or solicit votes within 75 feet of the polling place.

The location used to be one, but this year is not, Gilbertson said. The department addressed the mistake with the workers and Lesko, she said.

— Joshua Bowling

9:15 a.m.: First-time voters in the Ak-Chin Indian Community

Ak-Chin Indian Community had a quiet morning as people prepared for the day.

But at the tribe's community service center, slow but steady numbers of vehicles pull in as tribal members and community residents of the tribe exercise their right to vote.

Samantha Alejandro is married to an Ak-Chin tribal member. The mother of three arrived early to cast her vote. She said she is concerned with how fast the racial climate has changed. The first-time voter said she voted for Biden and Harris.

"I'm for peace," she said. "And we need to take steps to get there."

Another first-time voter had a different take.

"The way the president has handled the pandemic has been a disaster," said Jose Batopis III, 28.

Batopis, who's enrolled in the Yavapai-Apache Nation and also has Yaqui and Tohono O'odham heritage, lives in Ak-Chin and has lost an uncle, great-uncle and his grandfather to the coronavirus. He, too, voted for the Biden-Harris ticket. "They will take the country in a better direction," Batopis said.

Former tribal chairman and Elder Terry Enos has heard many candidate's promises for Indian Country.

"The president said he do a lot of things and did a 180 instead," Enos said. "Trump just doesn't get it."

On the other hand, Enos said that Biden walks softly but carries a big stick. He's not sure what will happen after the long count but still will urge his kids to come cast their vote.

Volunteers for Native Vote, a nationwide initiative that supports voting and deals with voting issues, were on hand for any problems. Anna Marie Smith and Annalise Parady came armed with brochures, information on the Native Vote Hotline for any problems and lots of water and snacks for the day.

— Debra Utacia Krol

9 a.m.: Mayoral races in Phoenix, Scottsdale and Gilbert

Phoenix's three-way race between incumbent Kate Gallego, Merissa Hamilton and Tim Seay is a primary election, meaning a candidate must get more than 50% of the vote to win outright on Tuesday. Otherwise, the race goes to a runoff between the top two vote-getters in March.

Both Scottsdale and Gilbert follow the more traditional election cycle in which the primary was held in August. Tuesday's runoff mayoral races feature Lisa Borowsky and David Ortega in Scottsdale and Matt Nielsen and Brigette Peterson in Gilbert.

Both Phoenix and Scottsdale have council races on the ballot, too.

The Scottsdale runoff features six candidates for three seats.

The Phoenix primary has contested races in the four council districts on the ballot. The most crowded race is in District 7, where five candidates vie to replace term-limited Michael Nowakowski representing parts of south, west and downtown Phoenix.

8:30 a.m.: Lines dwindle in Gilbert, West Valley

As lines at the Southeast Regional Library in Gilbert shortened after a busy morning, voters were able to get in and out of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints on Higley Road.

Veronica Parrillo, a first time nonpartisan volunteer, sat outside the polling place all morning to answer general questions that voters may have.

She said that the line had been moving pretty steadily.

"The longest I saw the line get was just over 20 minutes," Parillo said, adding that she expects more of a rush around lunchtime and later in the evening.

In Sun City West, lines had been virtually nonexistent since just after 6 a.m. Voters came by steadily but didn't have to wait in line.

Carolyn Gelazela volunteered to watch the polling location at the R.H. Johnson Recreation Center. Before she left her home Tuesday morning, her daughter reminded her to take her vitamins and told her not to be afraid of COVID-19.

The recreation center requires voters inside to wear a face covering. Most voters who came by Tuesday morning wore a face mask or other covering.

"I'm not a big believer in this whole pandemic thing. People are dying, but people die," Gelazela said, adding that she hopes for Republican victories as election results come in.

— Kelly Donohue, Adrienne Dunn

8 a.m.: McSally-Kelly Senate race captures eyes of the nation

The winner of the Arizona race to fill the seat initially won by the late Sen. John McCain could determine which party controls the U.S. Senate. Martha McSally, R-Ariz., and Mark Kelly, the Democratic challenger, fought hard in a high-profile, high-dollar race.

McSally, a former Air Force combat pilot, crisscrossed the state by plane on Sunday and Monday to visit 11 cities from Yuma to Kingman.

Recent polling suggests Kelly, a retired NASA astronaut, continues to lead in the race in the final days.

The winner likely will be on the ballot again in 2022; that's when McCain's term expires.

— Yvonne Wingett Sanchez

7:30 a.m.: Some voters see lines

Eric Kurland, a Democrat running for Arizona House of Representatives in Legislative District 23, visited the Islamic Center of the Northeast Valley in Scottsdale on Tuesday morning.

Kurland, a teacher, was clad in a T-shirt for his campaign and a face mask with symbols of education: sharpened pencils and bright red apples.

“I am just stunned by the amount of people that showed up this early for a vote that mostly everybody has already cast,” he said.

In Gilbert, Nicole Moon has been waiting in line to vote since 6:15 a.m. Tuesday. Moon, who works in communications, was still standing in line at the Southeast Regional Library in Gilbert shortly after 7 a.m.

She said she's concerned about unrest across the United States, no matter what the election results are.

"I think there's going to be a big political mess and probably some legal challenges," Moon said.

— Farah Eltohamy, Kelly Donohue

7 a.m.: Arizona is a battleground state this year. Here's why

Arizona is a magnet for transplants from across the country and has a large, Democratic-leaning Hispanic population that voted in more sizable numbers in 2018.

Along with a large independent electorate that swung mostly to Democrats two years ago, these factors helped push the state — once the base of GOP presidential nominees Barry Goldwater and John McCain — to battleground status.

Growing signs indicate these demographic trends could make it harder for President Donald Trump to hold on to a state he carried by 3.5% points in 2016. Recent polls show Biden in the lead.

— Ronald J. Hansen

6:30 a.m.: Voters waited for polling places to open

A steady stream of voters lined up early at the Southeast Regional Library in Gilbert.

Dozens were already waiting outside before the polling place opened at 6 a.m. The line grew and stretched into the parking lot within 30 minutes .

Voters were mostly masked and socially distanced as they waited to go inside and cast their votes.

Across the Valley in Sun City West, a short but steady stream of voters made their way into the active adult community's R.H. Johnson Recreation Center.

— Kelly Donohue, Adrienne Dunn

6 a.m.: Arizona polls open for historic 2020 election

Polling places are in new locations this election, and Maricopa County voters can cast a ballot at any polling place, now called vote centers, rather than at an assigned polling place. COVID-19 precautions are in place. Masks are available to voters who did not bring them.

Vote centers, ballot drop boxes and drive-thru drop boxes will be open from 6 a.m. until polls close at 7 p.m. Tuesday.

Locations for drop boxes and vote centers can be found at locations.maricopa.vote or by calling 602-506-1511.

For voters who:

Got a ballot in the mail but didn't send it back yet: Drop it off at any drop box or vote center.

Got a ballot in the mail but misplaced it: Get a new one at any vote center.

Want to vote in person: Go to any vote center. See here for what you should bring.

Overall, voting has gone smoothly since the county began opening vote centers and mailing out ballots on Oct. 7. By about noon Monday, the county had processed ballots for about 64.4% of the county's registered voters. That's about 1.68 million ballots out of 2.61 million registered voters.

By Sunday, early voting in the county had already surpassed total voting in 2016.

— Jen Fifield

search_result.title: P.F. Chang's, Kendra Scott among new stores coming to Christiana ...
search_result.text:
A slate of new stores are set to open at the Christiana Mall in the coming weeks as Delaware's top shopping hub readies for the holiday season.

But, perhaps the most anticipated newcomer is a year away.

P.F. Chang's is slated to open in late 2024, according to a company spokesperson.

P.F. Chang's appeared last November on the mall website's "coming soon" page and shortly after posted signs at the former Panera Bread on the west side of the mall between Nordstrom and Macy's. At the time, work on the restaurant was due to begin in early 2023 with an opening scheduled later in the year.

The winter holidays is the time most new mall businesses want to be open, but P.F. Chang's has failed to make significant progress fitting out the restaurant.

Here's what else has opened at the mall recently and is coming soon.

Kendra Scott

The jewelry and accessories store is opening across from two stores that came to the mall at the end of last year: Lululemon and Radcliffe Jewelers. It's also near the Apple store, making for one of the strongest sections of the mall, Christiana Mall General Manager Steve Chambliss said.

Chambliss said Kendra Scott stores are known, in part, for their community impact. A portion of sales "support women and youth in the areas of health and wellness, education, and entrepreneurship," according to the company's website.

The Christiana Mall store is expected to open in early November.

There are about 130 stores nationwide.

The space Kendra Scott is taking was previously tabbed for Savage X Fenty, the lingerie line from Rihanna. It was supposed to be one of the brand's first physical stores, but more than a year after the company first teased the location Savage X Fenty ultimately pulled out. Chambliss said the mall has tried to find them another space, but there is currently no planned location.

Tag Heuer

Tag Heuer, a Swiss luxury watch company, will open a store at the Christiana Mall on Nov. 15. The store is at a corner near Macy's.

Squishable

Next to Build-a-Bear in the Target wing, Squishable opened last month.

The store sells a variety of plush toys in the shape of everything from cartoon animals to foods like strawberry jam and sushi. And as the name indicates, the toys are meant to be squeezed.

They're softer than most stuffed animals, but not spongelike like a squishmallow. Each is anywhere from $10 to $55 depending on size and style, according to the Squishable website.

The Christiana Mall store is one of 33 Squishable-branded stores listed on the website. The products are sold in hundreds of gift shops and bookstores nationwide.

GROCERY: When will the Lidl in Bear open? Stormwater issue must be solved first

H&M recently renovated its store near Nordstrom. It closed for 90 days and returned with a sleeker, modern look.

Splash, a local retailer selling decorative soaps, opened in mid September near Macy's.

Stone Spirit, a store that sells crystals and games, recently opened between Perfume Shop Outlet and Lids near JC Penney.

Soleply, a store that buys and sells sneakers, recently opened between DTLR and Lush.

Like knowing what stores, restaurants and developments are coming and going in Delaware? Join our Facebook group What's Going There in Delaware and subscribe to our free What's Going There in Delaware newsletter.

Contact Brandon Holveck at bholveck@delawareonline.com. Follow him on X @holveck_brandon.

search_result.title: Kendra Scott opens at Christiana Mall November 3
search_result.text:
Kendra Scott, a jewelry and accessories store, is opening its first Delaware location in the Christiana Mall on Friday.

The store is across from Lululemon and Radcliffe Jewelers and next to Sephora in the Nordstrom wing. The Austin, Texas-based company has about 130 stores nationwide. They sell a variety of fine jewelry and gifts.

The Christiana Mall store will feature the company's latest store design. It has a color bar where employees work with customers to design custom products and an on-site engraving machine.

Kendra Scott has a reputation for its philanthropic efforts, giving to causes supporting women and youth in health and wellness, education and entrepreneurship. Kendra Scott regularly hosts "Kendra Gives Back" events in its stores.

Kendra Scott will celebrate its opening after the Black Friday rush in the first days of December. A portion of sales on Friday, Dec. 1, through Sunday, Dec. 3, will go to local organizations such as Cancer Support Community Delaware, the Miss Delaware Scholarship Organization, Saint Anne's Episcopal School and the Latin American Community Center.

More information can be found at kendrascottchristiana.splashthat.com.

WHAT'S GOING THERE: Wawa pulls proposal for drive-thru store in Newark. Other Newark store still planned

Kendra Scott will be open from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. on Monday through Saturday and from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Sunday.

The designer Kendra Scott founded the brand Kendra Scott in 2002. She sold jewelry to local boutiques around Austin and later national wholesale partners like Neiman Marcus, Nordstrom and Bloomingdale's. Scott began opening her own stores in 2010.

Two more new stores are expected at the mall this month, according to General Manager Steve Chambliss. Tag Heuer, the watch company, and Janie and Jack, a children's store, are scheduled to open before Black Friday.

P.F. Chang's is slated to open in late 2024, according to a company spokesperson. The restaurant is replacing the closed Panera Bread.
