search_result.title: Hunger in Delaware may be getting worse
search_result.text:
Saranac Hale Spencer

The (Wilmington, Del.) News Journal

WILMINGTON -- The number of people on food stamps in Delaware has dropped slightly over the last few years, but there are still people so hungry that they start eating out of their donation bag even before leaving a food pantry in Wilmington.

“Even with produce, they’ll sit down and start eating,” said Joseph Hickey, director of St. Patrick’s Center on the east side of the city.

People living in that kind of poverty are often overlooked, but they are living in Delaware and the deep poverty that has gripped them is spreading, Hickey said.

The percentage of people living below the federal poverty line across the state is 12.5 percent, according to the U.S. Census Bureau – that figure has crept up from 11.7 percent in 2013. Over that same time period, the number of people collecting SNAP benefits, or food stamps, in Delaware has fallen from just over 152,000 in 2013 to about 150,500 this year, according to numbers from the Delaware Department of Health and Social Services.

The adversity isn’t spread evenly across Delaware; there are pockets of deep want around the state. Nearly a quarter of Wilmington residents live below the poverty line.

Hunger in Central Jersey's backyard

Those who come to St. Patrick’s, in an old brick schoolhouse on a quiet corner, sign a form declaring that their annual income is below the federal poverty line before they can take home food.

“It’s a mere formality,” Hickey said, because they all live below the threshold.

“We’re talking about extreme poverty here,” he said, throwing his reading glasses down on a particle board desk with a ragged strip of its veneer missing on one corner.

Many of the people who come to the center have zero income, he said – they’re homeless. Others live on incomes scraped together from benefits or low-paying jobs.

For Delores Butcher, 54, who takes care of five grandchildren, the pantry at St. Patrick’s is the difference between having a house and being homeless.

“This place saved my life,” she said, sitting at one of the long, wooden tables in the center’s main room. The bookshelves standing against the wall and the nubby brown pile of the carpet make it feel like an elementary school classroom.

St. Patrick’s has been around since 1971, starting out as a senior center and evolving to serve the needs of the neighborhood.

Butcher first heard about it in 2000, she said, “but I didn’t come till seven years later.”

In 2007, Butcher found herself homeless for a short time, after having worked in clerical jobs since she left the Marine Corps in 1982.

“It’s been rough. And I mean rough,” she said, silver hearts dangling from her ears emphasizing the nod of her head.

She was born and raised in Middletown and many of her 13 brothers and sisters are still in the area, so she bounced around between them for a while until she could get back into a home of her own again. “I just kept going 'round and 'round,” she said.

Now she has housing through Section 8. She unplugs her microwave and TV when she’s not using them to save on electricity. Food is expensive, she said. Without the pantry at St. Patrick’s and the Sunday Breakfast Mission, which serves meals every night, she wouldn’t be able to afford everything.

“The rough part is Christmas time,” Butcher said. Last year, St. Patrick’s filled every single wish on her grandchildren’s lists. She had to take two trips to get all the gifts home. “I could barely see,” she said, because her eyes were filled with tears.

Donia Gonzales-Copeland, 67, helps run the food pantry at the Mount Salem UAME Church in Delaware City. She has always noticed the effect the holidays have on charity.

“It’s real funny, my mother pointed this out to me – people open up their wallets on Christmas and Thanksgiving,” she said. “Two times out of the year, people get food, the rest of the time it’s a crap shoot.”

November and December are big months for donations, Hickey said, and they fund much of their budget for the year then. The corporate and foundation grants they get have gone up since they’ve gotten more aggressive in pursuing them, he said, and the charitable donations from individuals have also gone up recently in response to the center’s growing need.

Salvation Army seeks better way to track poverty

Patricia Beebe, president of the Food Bank of Delaware, said her statewide organization has seen an increase in need, too. It’s been focusing on children – more than half of its programs are now geared toward young people – and every year, the demand for those programs grows, she said.

One in five children in Delaware lives in poverty, Beebe said.

The Food Bank started putting food closets in schools across the state about three years ago, she said. About 35 schools now have a place where children and parents can go to get food when they need it.

A year before that, the Food Bank started its backpack program, which sends enough food home with needy kids to get through the weekend. That program gets bigger every year, she said – it finished out the last year averaging about 5,400 backpacks a week.

There are a lot of people who don’t qualify for government assistance, but who are still very poor, Beebe said. So, as more people learn about the Food Bank’s programs, the bigger they get.

Sometimes, the demand for a program is much higher than an organization realizes, which is what Hickey found about six months ago when workers at St. Patrick’s started hearing that some senior citizens weren’t coming to the daily lunch because they didn’t have the $2 for the suggested donation. St. Patrick’s made the meal free and attendance tripled.

“People couldn’t afford two bucks,” he said.

“People here deal in pennies,” Hickey said, explaining the realization he came to after solving a minor mystery. Most people won’t even bend over to pick up a penny on the street, but at the end of the week when he’d go through petty cash gathered from the center’s sale of 35-cent coffee and 25-cent crackers, there were tons of pennies. He couldn’t figure out where all the pennies were coming from.

“Then it dawned on me – poor people use pennies,” he said. Twenty pennies and a nickel is a quarter for crackers.

“People don’t realize there’s another world out there and it’s a world of extreme poverty,” he said.

search_result.title: The editorial board endorses Kathy Jennings for attorney general
search_result.text:
The News Journal Editorial Board

Editor's note: This endorsement was decided solely by the editorial board and did not involve news reporters who cover elections.

The race for Delaware attorney general has been a bright spot in this election season.

From the Democratic primary all the way through this general election, all of the candidates have spoken eloquently about the urgent need to reform our criminal justice system.

There seems to be widespread agreement that racial and economic disparities in our courts and prisons must be addressed. All of the candidates rightly support the reduction of unjustly harsh mandatory minimum sentences, overhauling our unfair cash bail system, and reducing sky-high incarceration and recidivism rates.

The question in this election is, who is best positioned to make these reforms a reality? We think the answer is clear: Kathy Jennings.

Jennings has a formidable resume, having served as state prosecutor and chief deputy attorney general. She has a sterling reputation among state lawmakers, given her many years as a top official in the Department of Justice.

For example, she played a key role in eliminating the "three strikes" laws that imposed gratuitously tough sentences for minor crimes. This legislative experience is important, because many necessary reforms will require action in Dover.

While reform should be at the top of the next attorney general's agenda, there other important issues to tackle — and Jennings has the credentials for all of them.

She grappled directly with the opioid crisis as New Castle County's chief administrative officer. In the AG's office, she worked to combat gun violence. And she has personally prosecuted some of Delaware's highest-profile cases, so we can be confident in her ability to bring justice to those who truly deserve it.

Voters Guide:Learn more about the upcoming elections

We wrestled with this endorsement after interviewing Jennings' Republican opponent, Bernard Pepukayi. As someone who grew up in the Garfield Park area and faced drug charges as a teen, he compellingly argues that his life experience makes him uniquely suited to fight for a more just criminal justice system.

But we think Jennings' clout and reputation in Legislative Hall and decades of experience give her the best odds of actually getting reform across the goal line.

Jennings' opponents have questioned the depth of her commitment to criminal justice reform, insinuating that she is only taking these positions out of political expediency. Make no mistake, we give this endorsement with the expectation that Jennings will get results, and we will be keenly watching to make sure that her campaign promises are not empty.

But we're confident that Jennings' commitment to a better, fairer criminal justice system is real. And she's the best prepared to turn that commitment into reality.

search_result.title: $400 retiree bonus added to lawmakers' spending plan
search_result.text:
Retired state employees could see a $400 bonus in their pension checks later this year.

The Joint Finance Committee on Wednesday voted to include the one-time expense — valued at nearly $11 million — in the final budget proposal it will recommend to the General Assembly next month.

The bonuses are part of $73 million in new spending the panel has proposed beyond what Gov. John Carney had recommended in January. That amounts to roughly two-thirds of the $180 million in additional revenue added to the state's bottom line since the start of the year.

"I think it's wonderful news," said Germaine Hurst, a retired Mount Pleasant High School nurse.

"For a lot of us former state workers, our pension is our main source of income but it never goes up like the cost of our medication, food and gasoline," she said. "This isn't a long-term increase but I think it will help."

The bonuses would represent one of the first income increases approved for the 27,000 people who earn a state pension since 2015 when the General Assembly granted them a 1-percent, cost-of-living increase.

Yet officials with some state employee unions said they were hoping to see something more permanent.

“While we are appreciative of the funding increase for our pensioners, we have concerns that the increase for those on fixed incomes will not continue beyond Fiscal Year 2019 without further action from the General Assembly," said Mike Matthews, president of the Delaware State Educators Association.

State retirees have been "left in the lurch" for quite some time, said Mike Begatto, executive director of the Delaware chapter of the American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees.

"I think they were certainly seeking something longer term," he said. "But hopefully these bonuses will help them pay some bills."

The retiree bonuses approved by the JFC this week are in addition to the $500 bonuses the panel approved last week for current state workers — at a cost of $23 million.

Both bonus packages also are in addition to the 2-percent raises for public school educators and $1,000 pay hikes for other state workers included in Carney's spending plan.

"In 2009 when we were in a recession, the first area we went for relief was a salary reduction for state employees and I don't think they ever recovered," said JFC member Rep. J.J. Johnson, D-New Castle. "Currently, the state is at a 4-percent unemployment rate, which means you have to provide a decent salary to get employees."

Not all state workers are getting what they hoped for, however.

Carney's spending plan proposed funding nearly $15 million worth of pay raises for the state's roughly 1,280 correctional officers.

But the Correctional Officers Association of Delaware had been hoping the JFC would allocate additional funding to increase their pension, particularly beyond 25 years of service.

The enhanced benefits would have encouraged roughly 300 officers currently eligible for retirement to stay on the job longer and helped to attract new workers, according to COAD President Geoffrey Klopp.

"We're extremely disappointed," he said after JFC concluded its hearings without voting on the requested retirement package. "This is not going to do anything to help staffing and will cause people to have to work more, creating an unsafe working environment ... It just increases the chances of something catastrophic happening."

The JFC proposed a slew of other funding proposals on Wednesday totaling $23.5 million, according to a tally kept by state officials. Most were relatively small compared to the panel's overall $4.32 billion spending plan — an increase of 5.2 percent over the current fiscal year.

The panel this week agreed to include $4.1 million for school bus contractors to provide raises for their drivers.

It also agreed to allocate $2 million from the Tobacco Settlement Fund to restore a prescription drug assistance program that was completely gutted last year and another $400,000 in restored funding for the Delaware Breast Cancer Coalition's mammography van.

That spending comes after the JFC earmarked $92.5 million beyond the governor's recommended budget last week, including:

$46 million that will be carried forward a year to help the state cover costs in fiscal year 2020

$6.4 million for special education in grades K-3 and reading specialists in grades K-4

$4.7 million to improve services for nearly 5,000 adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities.

Another $61 million in projected revenue remained unspent as of Wednesday.

Some of that money will go to nonprofits as part of the annual grant-in-aid allocation, while the rest could be used cover one-time capital expenses or numerous other spending proposals now pending before the General Assembly – decisions that will be made in the waning days of the legislative session.

"We covered a lot of need," said JFC co-chair Sen. Harris McDowell, D-Wilmington, said of the spending plan crafted by the panel. "Not everything everybody thought they wanted, but a lot of need."

search_result.title: Delaware regional fishing report
search_result.text:
Bob Jones

Special to The News Journal

OCEAN

Catch reports from the bluewater fleet were good on days when winds and seas were calm enough to fish, with marlin and mahi providing most of the action for charters running out of Sunset Marina. The crew of the Espadon released two white marlin and put five gaffer dolphin in the cooler on a trolling trip to the Baltimore Canyon. The Baltimore also produced red hot mahi action for anglers aboard the Marlin, with 40 fish on ice at the end of the day. Fishermen aboard the My Cin connected with a cooler full of mahi while trolling a bit further south at the Poormans Canyon. The crew also released a nice white marlin on the trip. Deep water bottom bouncing outside the 50-fathom line provided plenty of action on a mix of blueline tilefish, golden tilefish and jumbo sea bass, with quality fishing reported from the area of the Baltimore Canyon south to the Norfolk. Boaters trolling and chunking at the Hotdog, Hambone, 19-Fathom Lump, Massey’s Canyon and the Teacup had reports of on and off action on bluefish, bonito, Spanish mackerel and schoolie mahi. The snags on the Del Jersey Land Reef and the deep-water wrecks outside the 20-fathom line are providing good fishing for a variety of popular species. Captain Cody Waddington of the Long Neck charter Another Bill returned from a recent wreck trip with a catch that included keeper sea bass, cod, ling and flounder. Wreck fishermen are reminded that the last day of the summer black sea bass season is Sept. 19. The fall season will open from Oct. 18 through Dec. 31, with a creel and size limit of 15 fish a day and a minimum keeper length of 15. Boaters targeting flounder are still reporting good fishing around the structure on Artificial Reef Sites Nine, 10 and 11, on the hard bottom at the Old Grounds and in the shipping channel around the DB and DA buoys. While a lot of the fish are measuring short of the 16-inch minimum, anglers who put in the time are generally rewarded with their share of keeper sized flatties. Captain Brent Weist of the Lewes charter Katydid has been on a roll when it comes to ocean flounder, with trip after trip producing good numbers of keeper-sized fish. Topping the weekly flounder reports from Captain Brent were a 6-pound citation for angler Ron Mistretta Jr. and one caught by Dave Walker that tipped the scale at 6 pounds 2 ounces. Most of the reports indicated short flounder to be a lot more common than keepers, but there also were a few real nice fluke caught by ocean fishermen. Anglers targeting flounder in the shipping lane and at Reef Sites 10 and 11 also are reporting good numbers of croaker, with some of the fish measuring more than 15 inches. Effective baits for the hardheads include bloodworms, strips of clean squid, bloodworm-flavored Fishbites and surf clams. Shore and boat fishermen also are catching a fair number of croaker in Indian River, Massey’s Ditch, Indian River Bay and Rehoboth Bay. There also have been reports of flounder being caught in Delaware’s back bays, but the number of keeper fish has been extremely low. Anglers checking in at Old Inlet Bait and Tackle are having some luck on legal rockfish along the inlet jetties at night, with sandfleas and live eel listed as the top producers. Surf casters are reporting increasing numbers of snapper bluefish along the Delaware beaches, according to the crew at Bill’s Sport Shop. Anglers stopping at the shop also reported croakers, kingfish, black drum and red drum in the local surf.

Don’t let rain dampen your deer hunt

DELAWARE BAY

Anglers fishing from the Cape Henlopen Fishing Pier scored on a mix of flounder, hardheads, spot, snapper bluefish, skates and a few small weakfish during the past week, with most reports listing squid, bloodworms, FishBites and Gulp! as the most productive bait choices. Shore fishing reports from the lower bay also included a mix of small trout, puppy drum, croaker, flounder and spot at Broadkill Beach, Beach Plum Island, Roosevelt Inlet and Lewes Beach. Boaters returning from the lower bay’s Artificial Reef Sites reported keeper-sized fluke on flounder rigs baited with minnow/squid combo baits, Gulp! Swimming Mullets, fresh strip baits and silversides. The mid and lower bay reefs also are a good choice for bottom-fishing action on hardheads, kings, pufferfish, porgies, small trout and snapper bluefish. Wade Guinn was fishing lower bay structure aboard the Angler when he landed a 3.34-pound trigger fish. The catch was weighed and reported by Joe Morris at Lewes Harbour Marina. Catch-and-release shark fishing led reports from boaters checking in at Smith’s Bait in Leipsic during the past week, with most of the action provided by brown sharks. Locations providing some of the best shark action included Miah Maul, Cross Ledge, the 10 buoy and Cedar Bush Hole. Reports from the shop also indicated good reef fishing action on flounder, croaker and bluefish in the upper bay at Artificial Reef Sites One and Two. Shore fishing reports from anglers stopping at Captain Bones Bait and Tackle indicated continued action on a mix of white perch, croaker and catfish at the Woodland Beach fishing pier, with bloodworms, squid strips and bloodworm Fishbites at the top of the bait list.

Aaron Nola may not get shut down before end of season

RIVERS

Catch reports from the crew at Master Baiter’s Bait and Tackle listed catfish and croaker as the primary focus of anglers fishing the Delaware River shore at Augustine Beach. Most of the fish are reportedly being caught on bloodworms or chunks of bunker. Anglers targeting largemouth bass enjoyed quality fishing in the tidal waters of the Nanticoke River while working deeper structure with Senko plastics. The Nanticoke has also been a top choice for jumbo catfish, according to fishermen stopping at Taylored Tackle in Seaford, with both channel cats and blue cats being caught. The top producers of big catfish are night crawlers, cut bait and chicken livers. The Route Nine Bridges in southern New Castle County topped the river reports from anglers stopping at Captain Bones Bait and Tackle, with most of the action coming from white perch and channel catfish. Reports from the crew at the shop also indicated good catches of blue crabs at Silver Run, Appoquinimink Creek, Drawyers Creek and Blackbird Creek.

PONDS

Largemouth bass led most of the pond reports, with some improvement in daytime fishing action noted over the past week. Bass fishermen checking in at Captain Bones Bait and Tackle reported good early morning fishing at Noxontown Pond, Garrisons Lake and Dover’s Silver Lake on buzzbaits and surface poppers. They also reported good afternoon fishing in the pond’s deeper areas while fishing crankbaits and Sweet Beaver lures. Catch reports from the crew at the Williamsville Country Store also were focused on largemouth bass, with Millsboro Pond and Killens Pond earning high recommendations. Topping the lure list for the ponds were Scum Frogs, jigs and buzzbaits. Hearn’s Pond continued to provide some of the best bass fishing action in the Seaford area, according to reports passed along by Jerry Taylor at Taylored Tackle, with topwater lures including poppers, Jitterbugs, buzzbaits and plastic frogs listed as top producers.

search_result.title: Body found in car at Wal-Mart after 3 weeks
search_result.text:
Terri Sanginiti

The News Journal

Authorities in Maryland are waiting for the state medical examiner to identity a woman found dead in a car at Wal-Mart in Elkton – three weeks after the vehicle was parked there.

The body was discovered about 3 p.m. Thursday by a groundskeeper at the store on U.S. 40 who noticed a foul odor and was searching for its origin, said Elkton police spokesman Lt. Joseph Zurolo.

The odor led to a silver 2002 Chrysler Sebring which was parked in an isolated place in the lot adjacent to the retention pond.

The groundskeeper then went to store managers, who notified police, Zurolo said.

Arriving officers and emergency personnel found the decomposed body of a woman lying in the back seat of the vehicle.

The remains were taken to the Office of the Maryland State Medical Examiner in Baltimore for autopsy.

Zurolo said a review of the store's surveillance video showed the car pulling into the lot on May 29.

"We can see a woman get out of the driver's side of the car and get into the back seat and is not seen again," he said.

No foul play was involved, Zurolo said.

The victim may be a missing woman previously reported to police, he said, not releasing further details.

"We're not sure, but it's possible," Zurolo said.

search_result.title: Joe Rogan, Greg Gutfeld, and the conservative comedy boom
search_result.text:
Greg Gutfeld smirked as he began reading off the teleprompter.

“Delta’s DEI officer has banned the term ‘ladies and gentlemen’ from airport announcements …” he said in a satiric tone. Then he hit the punchline: “And replaced it with ‘Dear customers of all gender identities, your flight is canceled, and your stewardess has a d---,” he said, using a crude word for the male anatomy.

The live studio audience that had gathered to watch the Fox News commentator-turned-late-night-host erupted in laughter and applause.

It’s the type of joke that might have appeared in the 1980s and 90s on sketch shows like "Saturday Night Live," and stand-up specials like Eddie Murphy’s "Delirious."

But as the culture has changed, and the country has become more polarized, not everyone is laughing anymore. Like many cultural touchstones, comedy viewership has begun to split along partisan lines.

Sign-up for Your Vote: Text with the USA TODAY elections team.

Now, a group of antiestablishment comedians has found a pot of gold serving a conservative audience. While these comics often say their jokes aren’t intended to be partisan, they largely cater to right-wing crowds looking for a reprieve from political correctness.

And in the last few years, their viewership has skyrocketed.

Ukraine is running out of weapons:Is it also running low on the time-tested coping mechanism of humor?

The burgeoning group includes personalities like Joe Rogan, Theo Von, and Gutfeld – who since 2021 has consistently ranked as the top-watched late-night comedian in America – beating out major network stars including Stephen Colbert, Jimmy Kimmel, and Jimmy Fallon.

Their popularity suggests the rise of a new conservative culture movement – one that GOP politicians and commentators are paying attention to.

Former President Donald Trump made waves in late August when he sat down for an episode of Von’s podcast, “This Past Week,” and his appearance on "Gutfeld!" in mid-September marked the ex-president’s first time on late-night television since 2016. Trump has also expressed a desire to appear on Rogan’s show, which ranks No. 1 on Spotify.

As Trump and the GOP attempt to grow their base, particularly among young men, these nontraditional, highly popular, comedic voices could provide the perfect avenue through which to reach them.

The void

The growth of conservative-leaning comedy over the last few years in many ways has mirrored the emergence of left-leaning satirists like Jon Stewart in the early 2000s.

Stewart, the host of Comedy Central’s "The Daily Show", gained popularity for mocking the idiosyncrasies of former President George W. Bush and his administration. While he took aim at both political parties, as well as the news media, Republicans were often the butt of his jokes.

Much of Stewart’s young audience at the time leaned liberal, and many thought of him as a news source. A 2004 Pew Research poll found that 21% of people ages 18 to 29 regularly got their election coverage from "The Daily Show" and other comedy programs like "Saturday Night Live."

Like the conservative comedians emerging today, however, Stewart didn’t view his show as expressly ideological. He acknowledged his own liberal biases but said in a 2005 interview with the Guardian that his foremost goal was to make people laugh.

By the time Stewart left his post as the full-time host of "The Daily Show" 10 years later, his influence was evident. Alumni of his show like Jon Oliver, Stephen Colbert and Samantha Bee, dominated the late-night comedy world.

Those, and many other late-night programs, had begun to lean into liberal points of view in their monologues. Few mainstream comedians were speaking to the perspectives of the millions of Republican viewers across the U.S.

More Democrats than Republicans watch late-night comedy, according to a YouGov poll published earlier this year. Half of Republicans said that these shows focus too much on politics and 57% said they're too liberal. Only 10% of Democrats saw the same political bias.

Nick Marx and Matt Sienkiewicz, authors of the book “That's Not Funny: How the Right Makes Comedy Work for Them,” argue that the void gave way to the rise of comedians like Gutfeld and Rogan.

“Many of them correctly assessed that there was a market for right-leaning comedy,” Marx, a professor of film and media studies at Colorado State University, said. “Whether they believed it or not, they leaned into it hard, and they’ve become … quite profitable.”

A political undercurrent

These comedians don’t think of themselves as overtly partisan.

Tom O'Connor, the executive producer of "Gutfeld!," said that while the late-night show airs on Fox News, a network associated with conservative viewpoints, it isn’t explicitly designed to appeal to people of a particular party.

“It’s just what’s funny to us,” said O'Connor. "Whether someone else wants to say, ‘Oh, this is conservative comedy,’ we don’t necessarily think of it that way.”

"Gutfeld!" has more Democratic viewers than some other late-night shows, including ones hosted by Fallon and Kimmel, according to Nielsen MRI Fusion data from July. But his audience overwhelmingly identifies as Republican. There were under 600,000 Democrats who watched his show in July, compared to 1.3 million Republicans.

And just as Jon Stewart holds more liberal stances, Gutfeld has a conservative point of view. Those personal beliefs at times seep into the show. When Trump was a guest, for instance, Gutfeld repeatedly described him as both the 45th and 47th president, though Trump is currently in a tight race to win the title for a second time.

The same goes for Rogan who, throughout his decades-long career, has made jokes about and expressed support for politicians on both sides of the political aisle. He has attempted to walk a careful line by defining his humor as more politically incorrect than overtly partisan.

But since 2020, Rogan has showcased far more right-leaning politicians and commentators on his podcast than left-leaning ones. They’ve included politicians like Rep. Dan Crenshaw, R-Texas, Tulsi Gabbard, and Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who have both endorsed Trump, and conservative commentators such as Ben Shapiro, Tucker Carlson, and Matt Walsh.

During an episode with Carlson, Rogan gave a rationale for why far-right radio show host Alex Jones spread conspiracy theories about the 2012 Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting in Newtown, Connecticut. Rogan described Jones as a “friend for more than 20 years.”

He said Jones' false claims about the shooting, which led Jones to pay a multimillion-dollar settlement to the families of the victims, stemmed from mental health issues – something he said some people receive “praise” for being honest about.

“Alex has gone through some real issues. And one of the reasons he has gone through some issues is because that guy is uncovering real s---- that’s terrifying every f------ day,” Rogan said of the conspiracy theories Jones promotes. "When you see so many lies, and so much propaganda and so many psyops that are being done on people, you start seeing them where they don’t exist. And that’s what he did."

Rogan also has often repeated pro-Trump talking points and false claims about Vice President Kamala Harris on his show. In an episode with conservative columnist Matt Walsh, he pushed the debunked conspiracy that Harris' pearl earrings during their recent presidential debate were secret Bluetooth earpieces. He later expressed doubt about the validity of Trump’s 34 felony convictions in his New York hush-money case.

“It is true that he's a convicted felon now, but is it true that it makes any sense? No,” Rogan said.

Marx and Sienkiewicz argue that, regardless of Rogan’s own political beliefs, the guests he has on, and the rhetoric he uses, are meant to embrace the more conservative-leaning viewers who watch his show. His personal political beliefs might be murky, but Sienkiewicz said “it’s very clear what his demographics are.”

His show, “The Joe Rogan Experience,” has been the most popular podcast in the U.S. for the past five years. He has more than 17 million subscribers on YouTube.

A majority of those listeners are young men, and nearly half identify as Republican, according to a 2022 study published by Morning Consult. Many of them hold similar beliefs to those that Rogan discusses in his show.

Only 12% of Rogan listeners surveyed in a 2022 YouGov Poll trusted newspapers to print the truth, compared to 27% of the general population.

Rogan is just the tip of the iceberg of conservative and libertarian-leaning comedy podcasts. His club in Austin, the Comedy Mothership, has cultivated a group of alternative comics who cater to a similar audience.

Von, who has appeared at the club and on Rogan’s podcast multiple times, hosts the ninth most listened to podcast on Spotify. Similar to Rogan, he hosted an early 2000s reality show – "Road Rules" – and frequently toes the line between politically incorrect jokes and mildly political conversations on his podcast.

One of the Comedy Mothership’s biggest stars, Tony Hinchcliffe, now ranks at No. 7 on Spotify’s comedy podcast charts. During a special episode of his show, "Kill Tony," in which Carlson and Rogan appeared, Hinchcliffe called the pair two of his “favorite humans on planet Earth.”

“He's trying, with some amount of success, to build a, you know, an alternative right-wing comedy space at his mothership in Austin,” Marx said of Rogan.

The 2024 impact

In a tight presidential race – where tens of thousands of votes could decide the election – both major political parties are looking for ways to appeal to key voters. And these highly watched and listened to personalities could influence enough voters to make a crucial difference.

While Harris and Democrats have leaned into memes to energize a younger voter base, Trump and Republicans have been trying to widen their base of support among men, particularly young men, who are target viewers for right-leaning comedy.

Republicans have long held leads among men in presidential elections, and this election is no different. A recent ABC News/Ipsos poll shows Trump leading Harris among men by 5 percentage points, 51% to 46%. In the latest USA TODAY/Suffolk poll, the breakdown of support of the 43% of respondents who said they’d vote for Trump shows that more than half (51%) are men, while 36% are women.

Trump’s campaign has attempted to further cultivate support among male voters by appearing with masculine cultural figures. Earlier this summer, the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee showcased speakers like Ultimate Fighting Championship CEO Dana White, a longtime friend of Trump's, and Hulk Hogan, a controversial professional wrestler who helped bring the sport into the mainstream.

Von, who interviewed Trump last month, and Rogan also both have ties to Ultimate Fighting Championship and White. The comedian Tyrus, who is a mainstay guest on "Gutfeld!," also dabbled in the fighting world as a professional wrestler. He gifted Trump a custom wrestling belt when the ex-president appeared on the show earlier this month.

Marx sees the convergence of comedy, the fighting world and politics as a potential boon for the Republican Party.

“It's all a very intentional push to get young men to vote,” he said of Trump's appearances with the comedians and fighters. “There's a real, sort of robust and growing market for conservative entertainment content and ... comedy is a precursor."

Contributing: Rebecca Morin.

This story has been updated to add new information, a title and the first name for Vice President Kamala Harris and to correct the misspellings of Tom O'Connor and Matt Sienkiewicz's names.

search_result.title: WILMAPCO seeking public comment on changes to Kirkwood ...
search_result.text:
Navigating Delaware’s road network can sometimes feel disorienting for both new and experienced drivers. Kirkwood Highway is a prime example. Driving along this four-to-six-lane roadway — or even trying to access it — can feel like a venture down a rabbit hole. For pedestrians and cyclists, attempting to traverse this busy thoroughfare often turns into a heart-pounding and potentially dangerous exercise.

To address challenges, transportation officials are developing plans to transform Kirkwood Highway from a high-speed corridor into a more community-friendly thoroughfare that better serves local residents and businesses. The project's latest developments were discussed at a public workshop Thursday, where officials presented draft recommendations for improving both transportation and land use along the highway.

Led by the Wilmington Area Planning Council, or WILMAPCO, the Kirkwood Highway Corridor Land Use and Transportation Plan envisions a redesign of an 8.3-mile stretch of Kirkwood Highway, also known as Route 2, where it intersects with State Routes 72, 7, 41, and 141. Including adjacent communities, the study area covers approximately 15 square miles.

The proposed updates would transform Kirkwood Highway into a more balanced transportation system with enhanced safety for drivers, cyclists and pedestrians while supporting economic growth and community development, according to WILMAPCO.

During the workshop, officials stressed the need for public feedback to ensure a comprehensive and inclusive planning process.

Converting Kirkwood Highway from a 'stroad' to street or road

Kirkwood Highway is marked by a unique combination of commercial and residential zones shaped by population changes and urbanization. Running as a four-to-six-lane divided highway between Newark and Wilmington, the western section is characterized by low-density development, parks and small strip malls adjoining suburban neighborhoods. In contrast, the eastern end transitions through major shopping hubs like Prices Corner and institutional landmarks such as the Wilmington VA Medical Center before passing through Elsmere.

Goals of the study seek to resolve key challenges related to accessing and traveling along the corridor. However, the design of Kirkwood Highway is a major complicating factor for potential changes.

Transportation experts classify the highway as a "stroad," a hybrid between a street and a road that serves neither purpose well. Their solution is to reconfigure sections of DE 2 to function either as a proper street or a road.

Public input is sought in eight categories, including public transportation, intersections, specific roads and connecting routes.

PAINTING THE TOWN:A new mural art project in Wilmington takes a 'roaring' look at the Jazz Age

The study pinpointed the most dangerous areas as the SR 141 junction, the Price's Corner area, and the intersection at Limestone Road (SR 7). Notably, SR 7 was identified as the most congested intersection in the study corridor, recording the highest number of crashes and the second highest in WILMAPCO’s statewide crash rankings.

Beyond these major trouble spots, the presentation also highlighted six additional intersections that need comprehensive study due to specific safety and traffic flow challenges:

Possum Park Road to address crash history and pedestrian accessibility Brewster Drive to address history of U-turn issues occurrences Green Valley to address history of U-turn occurrences Meadowood Drive to address crash history and pedestrian accessibility SR 100 (Dupont Road) to address intersection complexities SR 100 (DuPont Road) to address crash history

A reconfiguration of the SR 141 interchange and a bypass of the railroad crossing at Centerville Road and Newport Gap Pike is also being considered.

Despite projected population decline, there's room for new housing

The study plan reveals the impacted area is home to around 45,000 residents and supports 17,000 jobs. Although population projections indicate a potential decrease over the next 30 years, planners have identified a need for about 1,000 new housing units, particularly workforce housing. They suggest these units could be developed by repurposing certain existing commercial spaces.

Presentation materials, surveys and recordings are available on WILMAPCO’s website. For more information or to attend a future workshop, email Elizabeth Espinal at espinal@wilmapco.org.

You can contact Anitra Johnson at ajohnson@delawareonline.com.

search_result.title: DART seeks comment on bus route changes
search_result.text:
Yann Ranaivo

The News Journal

The Delaware Transit Corporation is seeking public input on proposals to change 19 DART bus routes across Wilmington and Newark.

DTC, the Delaware Department of Transportation division that runs DART, has scheduled open houses on Tuesday and Sept. 25 to give riders and the public the chance to review the proposed changes.

The first open house will take place at the Wilmington Public Library on East 10th Street, while the second will be at the Wilmington Area Planning Council at 850 Library Ave. in Newark.

"This is an extra layer of public outreach, and an additional chance to come out and review," said city Councilman Bud Freel, who also serves as DelDOT's legislative liaison for New Castle County.

Several of the changes would affect routes within city limits. For example, one route, Route 5, which includes stops from Rodney Square to Christiana Mall, would turn early on Ninth Street and no longer go to the park, a busy transit spot in the city.

John Sisson, DTC's CEO, said the Route 5 change would add eight one-way trips to the afternoon service, increasing frequencies from 30 to 20 minutes for the route that runs Monday through Friday.

Sisson said he will use the feedback from upcoming sessions to make any needed adjustments to the proposed route changes that his agency plans to enact in January. He said the public hearings at the Wilmington library on Oct. 28 and the Newark library on Oct. 29 will follow the open houses to gain more feedback.

Robert Smith takes the bus to travel from his home in north Wilmington to work at the Home Depot in Claymont.

Smith said he'd like to see an extension of the service hours to either midnight or 1 a.m. He said he often doesn't get off work until 11 p.m.

"I got to depend on taxis," he said.

The proposed route changes will also soon be posted in buses.

The route proposals are the result of nearly a year's work by various state and local groups seeking to improve rider experience. A part of their work culminated in the Wilmington Transit "Moving Forward" report, which among many other long-term proposals calls for route tweaks.

The report, which Sisson said has received positive feedback from figures such as Wilmington Chief Of Staff Cleon Cauley and Delaware Transportation Secretary Shailen Bhatt, is available at wilmapco.org/wilmtransitmoveforward.

The report includes so-called principles, or broad lists of proposed changes to the transit system over a period of more than 10 years. The principles include suggestions to deploy more environmentally friendly buses, improved bus technology to better assist riders and expand bus services.

"This is kind of like a first step," Sisson said, adding that the route changes can be enacted more quickly than the report's other suggestions.

Sisson said the proposals try to improve rider access to workplaces, boost ride frequencies and improve scheduling. He said the changes will cost little money because they will be made up of rearrangements.

"It's just putting the resources where they belong," Sisson said.

Note: This story has been updated to include the estimated cost of the city's consultant, Interface Studio LLC.

Wilmington is beginning a year-long effort to come up with a comprehensive plan that will guide development across the city for the next 10 years.

Officials are seeking public input for the plan, called Wilmington 2028, the city said in a news release.

Mayor Mike Purzycki said the plan will address current challenges and develop "a new vision for tomorrow."

"This will be a community-driven effort which I would like to see reflect the hopes and priorities of our citizens," he said in a statement. "This plan will guide future development, and shape where and why public and private investment dollars are spent to make Wilmington a stronger and more prosperous city over the next decade.”

The plan, managed by City Planning Director Herb Inden, is required by a Delaware law that states all municipalities must have a comprehensive plan in place that is reviewed and updated every 10 years.

The most recent plan on the city's website was adopted in 2003, updated in August 2009 and was certified by the state in 2010, the mayor's office said. It is accompanied by 11 neighborhood plans that provide the framework for setting land-use policy, the city said.

"The new comprehensive plan will combine all of the existing plans into one document that will better reflect the goals and aspirations of residents and city government for Wilmington’s future," the city's announcement said.

STORY: 'Significant enhancements' coming to Wilmington Council discretionary fund

STORY: CDC intervention plan for Wilmington teen violence lacks political will

The original comprehensive development plan was adopted between 1953 and 1959 by the Wilmington Planning Commission, according to the 2003 plan.

The city hired a Philadelphia-based urban design firm called Interface Studio LLC to assist with the effort. The company's contract and exhibits, obtained by The News Journal, show they will be paid an estimated $350,000.

The company began conducting initial interviews with "stakeholders" in mid-August, the city said.

The city is asking citizens to participate in an online survey that will "translate the vision, hopes, dreams, and priorities of our residents" into the city's guide: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/Wilmington2028.

The survey asks residents to rate their overall satisfaction and quality of life issues like safety, sense of community, affordability, commuting time, parks and recreation and housing.

The survey process will be followed by five public meetings to begin in late October and run through the end of November, the city said. In early 2018, focus groups will address specific issues and make recommendations. Preliminary recommendations will be submitted to the public for feedback in the spring of next year, the city said, and a draft of the new comprehensive plan will be shared with citizens in the summer of 2018.

Planning officials are hopeful that two proposals to redevelop a section of northeast Wilmington along the Brandywine River will line up and bring improved roads to an improved waterfront area.

The plans concern revitalization in an area from Vandever Avenue to the river between Market Street and Northeast Boulevard.

The Wilmington Area Planning Council, the transportation planning agency for New Castle County, has come up with three proposals to revamp roads in the area that would lead drivers toward the proposed riverfront development and away from homes.

A planning firm hired by Wilmington has been drafting an Environmental Protection Agency-funded report on ways to redevelop that area, which contains two contaminated former industrial sites.

Those proposals include new condominiums, a riverfront recreation park for walkers and kayakers, and a luxury hotel.

Brandywine River plans for condos, park met with caution by residents

All three proposed street plans would create a roadway along the Brandywine known as the "12th Street Connector" between Northeast Boulevard and the 16th Street bridge.

The plans begin at 12th Street where it meets Northeast Boulevard and extends that road eastward.

The plans would each cost over $7 million. After getting public input, the planners will choose one of the three proposals and then seek DelDOT funding.

The purpose is to divert traffic from cars exiting I-495, said WILMAPCO planner Dave Gula.

Currently, drivers going downtown from I-495's 12th Street exit either take Vandever Avenue to Route 13, or drive south on Northeast Boulevard into East Side streets. Both of those routes cause significant traffic in mostly residential areas, Gula said.

Planners are hoping the traffic would flow into an extended 12th Street instead, which they are also designing to be pedestrian- and bike-friendly so that residents can use it to access proposed parks and other development along the river.

Two of the street plans align with the two proposed redevelopment plans.

Sean Garrigan of Stromberg/Garrigan and Associates, the firm drafting the redevelopment proposals, said he plans to wait for WILMAPCO to choose its preferred road design so the firm can choose a corresponding redevelopment plan.

A report on recommended redevelopment plans is due to the city by the end of March.

Redevelopment has been anticipated for over two decades in the neighborhood, which has disproportionately high rates of poverty and unemployment and an aging building stock.

The state established the Riverfront Development Corp. in 1995 to redevelop the Brandywine and Christina waterfronts. When Mayor Mike Purzycki was executive director of the group, plans along the Brandywine were put on hold in favor of the Christina riverfront.

Residents hope to be part of Brandywine waterfront redevelopment

The redevelopment proposals include over 100 new 1- and 2-bedroom market-rate apartment units from Spruce Street to Locust Street, a trail and park along the riverfront, and retail units on North Market and Hutton streets. Condos or a hotel could be built near those shops.

search_result.title: Effort to protect Red Clay Valley in Delaware
search_result.text:
Xerxes Wilson

The News Journal

Local land planners are embarking on an effort that will influence the future face of the Red Clay Valley in northern New Castle County.

The effort will mold public input into recommendations for county land use officials on how development should be allowed in the future in an attempt to preserve the scenic nature of the Red Clay Valley Scenic Byway.

The Red Clay Valley Scenic Byway – made up of some 28 secondary roads in the Red Clay Creek watershed – is bounded on the north by the Pennsylvania state line, on the east by the Kennett Pike, on the south by Barley Mill Road and on the south and west by Lancaster Pike and is characterized by a countryside vibe.

The Delaware Nature Society’s 2004 nomination of the roads was accepted into the Scenic and Historic Highways as the state’s second designated byway in 2005. Planners are now crafting suggestions for an overlay – which is a set of regulations that would protect the resources and characteristics identified by the designation.

Those characteristics are both aesthetic and more tangible, like the watershed itself and historic properties like what is left of the paper mill industry in Yorklyn.

The byway’s narrow roads wind between steep slopes and thick forests, through covered bridges and across ridge lines with scenic views of meadows below. But the countryside character and short hop from Wilmington is also very attractive to those looking for place to live. This has some residents fearing the area’s character will be marred by development.

“This is not necessarily bad,” said John Gaadt, a consultant hired for the effort, as he showed those attending a public workshop a photo of a housing development in the area called Videre Woods. “I kind of refer to this as suburban creep. What we see over time is a little bit of the byway changing ... The question is, is this going to protect what we are trying to protect and enhance?”

Heather Dunigan, a transportation planner with the Wilmington Area Planning Council, which is partnering with several other organizations on the project, said the area has a standard suburban zoning so there is a disconnect between what is allowed and what would be considered in the area’s character.

“You can’t stop progress, but it shouldn’t be seen from the road,” said one resident at the workshop.

Much of the discussion at the public workshop, which was the first of many to gather input from residents, centered around aspects of the area that can be enhanced and what residents see as potential threats.

“I live near the Mt. Cuba observatory and the light is really becoming a problem,” said resident Cindy Gamble.

Other discussions included deer fences, how homes should look in the area, traffic and a particularly unsightly yellow home sticking out atop a hill.

“There is no direct way through here and that is part of the character,” said resident Bill Kissell.

Residents also discussed the need for greater hiking access to Hoopes Reservoir and returning the various waterways in the watershed to a more natural flow

“With the beauty and the hills, it is an ideal place for bikes if there were no cars,” one resident opined.

The end product will take the form of suggestions for how code should dictate things like what types of developments are allowed and how far homes should be set back from the road. The recommendations will be used by the county to craft rules which must be ratified by council, county land use officials said.

“Everybody loves the byway as it is and they don’t want anything to change,” said resident Bill Bizjak.

The next public workshop will be held in spring. The process is being funded by a WILMAPCO grant and will take between 8 months to a year to complete.

For more information visit www.wilmapco.org/redclay

search_result.title: Brandywine Hundred arterial loses funding for sidewalk
search_result.text:
Karl Baker

The News Journal

Plans to build a sidewalk along a dangerous one-mile stretch of Grubb Road in Brandywine Hundred have been stalled after the project was removed by state officials from a list of funded transportation ventures.

Grubb Road is lined by tree-shrouded suburban homes and ties subdivisions together between Faulk and Naamans roads. A bar sits along the street's intersection with Foulk Road, and four schools lie about a mile or less from the stretch of roadway.

But Grubb Road between Majestic Drive and Country Gates Drive has no sidewalk, no paved shoulder, and hedges that sprout up directly next to the roadway in places. For about a decade, residents and state officials have tossed about plans to build a sidewalk so that pedestrians can safely walk.

But disagreements over where to place it have kept the idea from materializing.

"Everybody wants the same thing. We need a freaking sidewalk, it's dangerous ... if you're walking up the street," said Mike Kiernan, an independent contractor who lives on Grubb Road. "It's just nobody wants it on their side of the street ... and I don't really want it on my side of the street either."

As a result of the disagreement, officials said, the Grubb Road sidewalk was the only planned future project to be removed from the Wilmington Area Planning Council's recent $2.3 billion priority list for transportation projects.

Approximately $550,000 had been directed to fund engineering and right-of-way purchases for sidewalk construction on Grubb Road last year, said Heather Dunigan, principal planner at WILMAPCO.

That funding has been rescinded.

"It's an area where people need to walk but have nowhere to do it safely," said Dunigan. But "my understanding is (DelDOT) removed the funds because they didn't feel there was consensus" among residents.

Along with the Delaware Department of Transportation, WILMAPCO plans roads, bridges and transit projects that are partially federally-funded in New Castle County.

Now that the Grubb Road sidewalk project has been removed from the WILMAPCO's priority list, it won't be funded for at least three years, said Drew Boyce, DelDOT's director of planning.

The project has not been scrapped, however, he said, as it has been placed on another DelDOT project wishlist, called the Capital Transportation Plan. Now, it is one of numerous unfunded projects on that queue.

"We still think it's a viable transportation project," said Boyce. "Just because it's hard (to gather consensus) doesn't mean we're not going to try again."

STORY: Man injured after fall from bike in Brandywine Hundred

STORY: New Castle County seeks solution for historical homes

New Castle County Councilman Robert Weiner, who has been an advocate of a sidewalk for years, said transportation officials should not have allowed a "minority" of vocal residents to ax the project. DelDOT's role, he said, is not to achieve a complete consensus but rather to move forward with projects that will increase the safety of residents.

"Brandywine Hundred citizens have been shortchanged," Weiner said. "A few people's contrary opinions should not dissuade DelDOT from moving forward with a plan the majority supports."

Joe Iacono, a landscaper and Grubb Road resident, noted that a sidewalk could increase home values along the road, in addition to safety benefits.

"It's not going to affect anybody's curb appeal in my eyes," he said. "A sidewalk or a bike path is beneficial."

Kiernan said he other neighbors do worry about burglaries in the area, and a sidewalk could make it easier for thieves to "scope out" a home.

After a few minutes of contemplation, however, he noted that no one is ever going to be completely satisfied.

"You almost want (a sidewalk) to go on both sides of the street...then nobody can complain," Kiernan said.

search_result.title: Appoquinimink school referendum overwhelmingly passes
search_result.text:
Jerry Smith

The News Journal

Three new schools and a host of other school upgrades related to growth will be a reality in the Appoquinimink School District as voters overwhelmingly approved a $268 million capital referendum Tuesday.

Unofficial results from the Department of Elections show 5,152 votes for and 2,496 votes against the first question, which gives the district $3.1 million in operational funding.

A similar margin was seen for the second question, which gives the district money to build new schools and renovate others. Unofficially, there were 5,506 "yes" votes and 2,102 "no" votes.

The department will certify the results of the referendum at 2 p.m. Thursday, said Elections Unit Manager Barbara Lippincott.

Appoquinimink Board President Richard Forsten said the overwhelming "victory" was realized through a well thought-out plan and volunteers getting the word out in all communities in the district.

"The district put a lot of time and thought into the planning that went into this, and the voters responded," Forsten said. "We work awfully hard as a school board and care very much about education in this district. Education is one, if not the most important, thing government can do, and we want to continue to be a good school district."

Appoquinimink Superintendent Matt Burrows said the real work begins now that the community has put its faith in the district, deemed the fastest-growing in the state.

"We have to use the money we were granted wisely," he said. "The community came out and spoke tonight, and they deserve nothing but the best from us. We will now hit the ground running. We have three new schools to build."

Because of the growth the school district has seen in the past and is predicting in the future, officials saw a need to host a two-part referendum – one ballot item sought funding to build and expand schools, while the other sought funds for operational expenses.

In the last two years, Appoquinimink School District – which largely encompasses Middletown, Odessa and Townsend – has added 766 students. Since 2006, the district has 3,082 additional students and has a current enrollment of 10,644. Last year alone saw a more than 500-student increase.

That growth will continue as the population in the Appoquinimink School District is projected to increase significantly in the coming decades, from 66,429 people in 2015 to 89,892 people by 2025 and 107,206 people by 2035, according to WILMAPCO, a federally designated metropolitan planning organization used by the district to project growth.

The district will now be able to build a 1,600-student high school and 1,000-student middle school on the Fairview Campus, where they will join the existing kindergarten center and elementary school. This will create the first K-12 campus in the state.

A new 840-student elementary school is also planned in the town of Whitehall on land that was donated to the district.

The district also has plans to redesign and expand Everett Meredith Middle School to allow for 1,000 students and to renovate Silver Lake Elementary School.

STORY: Residents feel forced out of Magnolia development

STORY: Middletown students pull of Wreaths Across America welcome

As a stop-gap measure, the district has added trailers to two middle schools and an elementary school, but temporary solutions were costly, with nearly $1 million spent and leasing fees.

Cedar Lane Elementary School and the district’s two high schools also repurposed spaces as classrooms, moved to “on-a-cart” instruction and are currently sharing rooms.

The price tag to fund the capital improvements is a little more than $268 million, of which 25 percent ($67.1 million) will be paid for by taxpayers through the referendum and 75 percent paid for by the state. That equates to 8.54 cents per $100 of assessed home value, which will range from about $5 a month for a house valued at $150,000 to about $14 a month for a home valued at $450,000.

Appoquinimink was one of only two school districts to be approved for capital support from the state among five that applied this year. The state prioritized districts that showed critical enrollment issues.

The second question on the ballot sought $3.1 million for such things as teacher recruitment and retention, technology and operating expenses. The tax impact for this part is 15 cents per $100 assessed value of a home.

Middletown High Principal Matthew Donovan said before the referendum vote that he believes great outcomes require great teachers and support staff. He also said more funding was needed to attract and retain good teachers.

"We ask so much more from our teachers every day. Keeping quality teachers here is important,” he said. “The worst thing that can happen after they’ve practiced, become refined and are successful, is they leave. The investment in that teacher is lost if they go somewhere else.”

Some of the money will be used for technology.

“Learning, and especially 21st-century learning, is different than when most parents went to school,” Burrows said. “You are seeing more devices. Learning is no longer just happening between the four walls of the school building. It’s happening at home. It’s happening at the coffee shop. Learning is happening almost 24/7 because of student connectivity to the devices. We need to prepare our kids for the jobs that are out there and the jobs we don’t even know exist at this point as they move forward."

With the referendum passing, taxpayers will pay 23.54 cents per $100 of their home's value, which could be anywhere from $9 a month ($150,000 home) to $27 a month ($450,000 home).
